title: Russia withdraws from Chernobyl in Ukraine
content:
**Sunday, April 3, 2022**

On Thursday, Ukraine reported and the IAEA confirmed that Russian forces had withdrawn from the abandoned Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant, the site of the world's worst nuclear disaster in 1986. State-owned enterprise Energoatom, which oversees Ukraine's nuclear facilities, stated that Russian soldiers were exposed to radiation while digging trenches in the Red Forest within the Chernobyl Exclusion Zone. Although the IAEA acknowledged the troop withdrawal and their movement towards Belarus, it did not confirm the reports of radiation exposure. Russia took control of Chernobyl during the early stages of its invasion of Ukraine, which began on February 24. The last Russian troops were reported to have departed early Friday morning.

title: Fallen power cable kills 26 in Congo-Kinshasa
content:
Friday, February 4, 2022

At least 26 people were killed on Wednesday in the outskirts of Kinshasa, Democratic Republic of the Congo, when a lightning strike caused a high-tension electric power cable to fall near a marketplace. 

The country's energy provider, Société Nationale d'Électricité, confirmed that the incident occurred during a severe storm and expressed condolences to the victims' families. Reports from local media and police indicate that the tragedy took place in the Matadi-Kibala district, with most of the electrocution victims being women employed at the market. 

Prime Minister Jean-Michel Sama Lukonde expressed his grief in a statement, saying, "I share the immense pain of the families. My thoughts are also with all the injured." A government spokesperson revealed that a crisis meeting was convened to discuss the relocation of the market.

The BBC quoted one vendor who noted that heavy rains frequently forced buyers and sellers to navigate through flooded areas in the market.

title: Northern Ireland First Minister Paul Givan resigns over Brexit border checks
content:
**Friday, February 4, 2022**

**The Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) First Minister of Northern Ireland, Paul Givan, Resigns in Protest Against Brexit Checks**

Paul Givan, the First Minister of Northern Ireland and a member of the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP), has resigned effective midnight Friday in response to his party’s protests against checks on goods coming from Great Britain, a requirement established under the Northern Ireland Protocol during the Brexit negotiations.

Unionist leaders in Northern Ireland have vehemently opposed the terms of the Protocol, which has been a contentious issue since the UK’s departure from the European Union. Givan’s resignation also means that Sinn Féin Deputy First Minister Michelle O'Neill will be removed from office, leading to a paralysis of the devolved Executive at Stormont. This development hinders the legislative body's ability to enact crucial policies, including a three-year budget, an energy bill grant, and the relaxation of Covid-19 restrictions. Nevertheless, other Stormont ministers will continue in their roles until the next elections are held in May.

In an emotional press statement, Givan remarked that the institutions of Northern Ireland are "being tested once again," noting that the delicate balance established by the Belfast and St Andrew's agreements has been affected by the UK-EU Brexit agreement. He cited the "cornerstone" principle of consent included in the Belfast Good Friday Agreement, which led to the creation of the power-sharing Executive. Despite his resignation, he expressed his "earnest desire for all sections of the community to soon be able to give consent to the restoration of a fully functioning executive through the resolution of the issues that have regrettably brought us to this point."

Givan described his resignation after nearly eight months in office as "the end of what has been the privilege of my lifetime - to serve as the First Minister of Northern Ireland," highlighting that he never expected to have this opportunity when he was first elected as Lagan Valley MLA in 2011, succeeding Arlene Foster after her resignation in June 2021.

Opposition parties have criticized the decision, labeling it "reckless and self-serving," particularly by Sinn Féin finance minister Conor Murphy, and officials from both the British and Irish governments. Sinn Féin leader Mary Lou McDonald called for an early election, emphasizing that "the DUP's actions have consequences, real consequences for people struggling." Ulster Unionist Party leader Doug Beattie denounced the resignation as destabilizing, stating it creates "more hardship for the people of Northern Ireland" and is ultimately pointless, as "the Protocol will still be there."

While McDonald condemned the inaction on the budget and healthcare investment as driven by "the DUP's narrow and self-serving political interests," others voiced alarm over the potential paralysis of government services. UK Secretary of State for Northern Ireland, Brandon Lewis, described the move as "extremely disappointing" and urged for reinstatement to "ensure the necessary delivery of public services for the citizens of Northern Ireland." Prime Minister Boris Johnson reiterated the UK government's commitment to a resilient Northern Ireland Executive.

Taoiseach of Ireland Michéal Martin characterized Givan’s resignation as "a highly damaging move." Through a spokesperson, he stressed that "it is absolutely vital for peace and prosperity in Northern Ireland that the Executive is delivering for the people, especially as we emerge from the Covid pandemic." He urged the DUP to fully engage with all the institutions of the Good Friday Agreement, which the Protocol safeguards.

Martin also indicated that ongoing talks between the UK and EU, of which Ireland is a member, "must be given every chance to succeed." He mentioned that the European Commission has proposed serious initiatives addressing implementation issues related to the Protocol. Givan had previously told reporters that he was resigning because Unionists were being required "to be seen and not heard" regarding the Protocol.

On Thursday, British Foreign Secretary Liz Truss and European Commission Vice President Maroš Šefčovič held a video conference to discuss the Protocol, which they view as the "only solution" to protect the Good Friday Agreement. Šefčovič labeled Agriculture Minister Edwin Poots’s recent decision to suspend certain checks for goods entering Northern Ireland as "very unhelpful." The two will reconvene on February 11.

Unionist politicians have firmly voiced their stance on the Protocol. Following Givan's resignation, DUP party leader Sir Jeffrey Donaldson stated it "represents an existential threat to Northern Ireland's place within the Union." He criticized the UK government for not upholding the New Decade, New Approach agreement, which facilitated the DUP’s return to the Executive in January 2020, ending a three-year stalemate after the Renewable Heat Incentive scandal.

According to the Irish Independent, the timing and particulars of Givan's resignation were confirmed in a meeting among senior DUP members earlier on Thursday. Poots's directive to halt sanitary and phytosanitary checks not mandated by December 31, 2020, reportedly followed legal advice suggesting that he could cease checks without Executive approval. While the UK government maintained that it would not intervene in what it sees as a matter for the Northern Ireland Executive, it faced accusations of breaching international law from Irish Minister for Foreign Affairs Simon Coveney. Šefčovič asserted that it is essential for checks to continue, while a spokesperson for Johnson expressed support for "a swift resolution."

title: Washington D.C. football team replaces controversial name with "Commanders"
content:
**Friday, February 4, 2022**

The American football team based in Washington, D.C., announced on Wednesday during the Today Show that it will be adopting the new name, the Washington Commanders. Previously known as the Washington Redskins, the team has faced longstanding criticism from Native American organizations, which argued that using names like "Redskins" perpetuates offensive stereotypes. Unlike terms such as "Indians" or "Braves," the term "Redskin" is recognized by many, including Ray Halbritter of Oneida Nation Enterprises, as "a dictionary-defined slur."

On Wednesday, team president Jason Wright expressed that the new name "embodies the values of service and leadership that characterize the DMV [D.C., Maryland, Virginia region]." Current and former players Jonathan Allen and Gary Clark praised the team's new uniforms, which prominently feature a letter "W." Allen noted that while the name itself doesn't hold historical significance, the excitement generated by players showcasing their new uniforms is sure to engage fans.

Team owner Daniel Snyder had long resisted a name change, even once suggesting he would capitalize the name. However, in June 2020, a coalition of 87 sponsors, including FedEx, Nike, and Pepsi, urged the team management to change the name, highlighting the growing backlash against its use. The decision to rebrand was influenced by feedback from fans, a former player, and Native Americans, led by consultant John Wright. Although fans expressed interest in variations of "Red Wolves," many related names and imagery had already been trademarked.

Responses from Native American leaders have been mixed. Crystal Echo Hawk of IllumiNative stated that the team has an opportunity to "put a horrible chapter to rest," but emphasized that "there's still a lot of healing that needs to happen," indicating that the team's efforts toward reconciliation are not yet complete. 

Fawn Sharp, president of the National Congress of American Indians (NCAI), criticized the team's management for failing to adequately address the harm caused by the former name. She stated, "Without an apology, without any measure of accountability, and without fulfilling the honored commitments they made to tribal nations in 2020 to right this wrong, the NFL and Snyder are simply 'Commanding' a continued course of open, intentional, and profit-driven racism and erasure."

Currently, approximately one thousand sports teams in the United States use Native American-themed names, a decrease from around three thousand in the 1990s. Organizations like the American Indian Movement and NCAI continue to advocate for these teams to transition to non-Native American names and mascots.

title: Fire destroys central market in Somaliland's capital
content:
**Monday, April 4, 2022**

A fire erupted on Friday at the Waheen Market in Hargeisa, the capital of Somaliland, injuring 28 people with no reported fatalities. The blaze started around 20:00 EAT (17:00 UTC) and posed challenges for firefighters who managed to gain control of the situation by early Saturday morning. The cause of the fire remains under investigation.

Somaliland President Muse Bihi Abdi visited the market and announced a pledge of USD 1 million in aid, estimating that the damage caused by the fire could amount to millions of dollars. Waheen Market, which houses over 2,000 stores, is integral to Hargeisa's economy, contributing to 40-50% of the city's commercial activity, according to Jamal Aideed, chairman of the Hargeisa chamber of commerce. The incident occurred as the city, with a population of 1.2 million, was preparing for increased activity for the first day of Ramadan.

In response to the tragedy, Somali President Mohamed Abdullahi Mohamed reached out to offer his condolences. Additionally, Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed and former UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson have extended their support.

Since declaring independence from Somalia in 1991, Somaliland has operated as an autonomous region, though it has yet to gain international recognition.

title: Ballarat residents protest for climate action
content:
**Tuesday, May 3, 2022**  
**Ballarat, Australia** — On Sunday, the rural city of Ballarat witnessed a rally for climate action as residents took to the streets. The event commenced at 1 PM outside the Ballarat Civic Hall, with participants marching along Mair, Lydiard, and Sturt Streets, and passing by the office of local MP Catherine King, before arriving at the Ballarat Town Hall. There, representatives from several organizations, including Ballarat Renewable Energy and Zero Emissions (BREAZE), the Ballarat branch of Extinction Rebellion, Environment Victoria, the Public Transport Users Association, and the Ballarat Trades Hall, addressed the crowd. Although no political candidates spoke at the event, independent candidate Alex Graham and Greens member John Barnes, both contenders for the Ballarat seat in the upcoming federal election, were in attendance.

title: Australian Open: Nadal wins 21st Grand Slam
content:
**Tuesday, February 1, 2022**

On Sunday, Spanish tennis player Rafael Nadal secured his 21st Grand Slam singles title at the 2022 Australian Open, defeating Russian competitor Daniil Medvedev.

There were concerns regarding Nadal's ability to compete in the tournament due to a foot injury. The match began with Medvedev taking an early lead, winning the first set 6-2 in just 42 minutes. Nadal rebounded, claiming the fourth set 6-4, and ultimately clinched the victory in the fifth set with a score of 7-5 after an intense battle lasting 5 hours and 24 minutes.

With the absence of his top rivals, Novak Djokovic and Roger Federer, Nadal surpassed them to become the record-holder for the most men's singles titles. In his on-court interview, Nadal remarked, "It has been one of the most emotional matches in my tennis career, and to share the court with you [Medvedev] was an honor."

Medvedev expressed gratitude to his team following the match, noting, "I'm sure my wife is watching back home, but I think the TV will be broken now." Acknowledging his defeat, he commented, "He [Nadal] was really strong; the way he played for four hours surprised me."

Nadal reached the finals after triumphing over Italian player Matteo Berrettini in the semi-finals. Last year was challenging for Nadal, as he missed Wimbledon due to fatigue and the US Open due to his foot injury. Reflecting on his journey, Nadal stated, "One month and a half ago, I would have said it would be my last Australian Open, but now I have a lot of energy to carry on." Despite feeling "physically destroyed" and exhausted, Nadal celebrated his victory in the post-match interview.

title: Deadly floods in Brazil after heavy rainfall
content:
Tuesday, February 1, 2022 

São Paulo state in Brazil has been severely affected by heavy rainfall since Friday, resulting in at least 24 fatalities and displacing thousands of residents. With 27 cities affected, Governor João Doria announced on Sunday the mobilization of emergency services to assist in the impacted areas. The government reports that approximately half a million families have been forced to evacuate their homes, and many highways and roads have become impassable. São Paulo is not only Brazil's most populous state but also home to the country's largest city, São Paulo.

title: UAE to impose corporate tax on business profits
content:
**Tuesday, February 1, 2022**

On Monday, the United Arab Emirates announced a new federal corporate tax of 9% on business profits, set to take effect on June 1, 2023. This tax will apply to all businesses except those engaged in the extraction of natural resources. Companies with profits up to 375,000 dirhams will be classified as small businesses and will be exempt from the tax.

Historically, the Emirates has maintained a low tax environment, with no personal income tax. The Ministry of Finance stated that the introduction of this corporate tax aims to combat tax avoidance and align the country with global developments, particularly concerning the digitalization of the economy. While it may relate to a recent international agreement on a minimum global corporate tax rate, the Ministry did not provide further details.

title: Brothers Sunshine Coast pick up first win in senior rugby at Australia's University of the Sunshine Coast
content:
**Brothers Sunshine Coast Secures First Senior Rugby Union Win**

On Friday night, Brothers Sunshine Coast achieved their inaugural victory in senior rugby union, defeating University 10-5 in Round 4 of the Sunshine Coast Cup at Sippy Downs, Australia.

"It was fantastic," said Brothers second rower Kalani O'Neill in an interview with Wikinews. "While the conditions could have been better—it was a bit wet—we played as a cohesive unit and were fortunate to secure the win. In the end, it was a strong performance."

The inclement weather significantly influenced the match, with a heavy downpour earlier in the day rendering the ground waterlogged. Both teams opted to maintain a close-quarters style of play centered around the breakdown.

O'Neill praised his teammate Jacko Jackson for his outstanding performance, stating, "He brought intensity throughout the entire game. He consistently targeted players and made crucial tackles. Our other Jack really contributed by making space for us in the corners and helping us advance."

Despite the encouraging win, O'Neill emphasized that the team would not let this result define their season. "We've got 12 more rounds ahead," he remarked. "So we might as well aim high and keep pushing forward."

title: Indian Prime Minister Modi attends 5th BIMSTEC summit virtually
content:
**Friday, April 1, 2022**

On Wednesday, Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi participated in the fifth Bay of Bengal Initiative for Multi-Sectoral Technical and Economic Cooperation (BIMSTEC) summit, which was held virtually and chaired by Sri Lanka. 

The summit was centered around the theme "Towards a resilient region, prosperous economies, healthy people." In his opening remarks, Prime Minister Modi expressed optimism that the summit could herald a golden chapter in history. He announced a commitment of USD 1 million to the BIMSTEC secretariat to enhance its operational budget, along with USD 3 million for the development of the BIMSTEC Centre for Weather and Climate, which is expected to play a crucial role in disaster management for the region.

Additionally, the member states signed an official BIMSTEC charter, formalizing the grouping into a structured regional organization. Three significant memorandums related to security, technology, and diplomacy were also agreed upon during the summit. Leaders discussed a "Master Plan for Transport Connectivity," aimed at improving regional transportation and movement.

Modi emphasized the need for further development of BIMSTEC, touching on topics such as maritime cooperation, disaster management, economic integration, and security. He advocated for mutual free trade among member states and, in light of recent upheavals in Europe, called for enhanced regional cooperation to ensure stability.

The summit underscored the importance of utilizing the Bay of Bengal as a "bridge of connectivity, prosperity, and security." At the conclusion of the summit, chairmanship was handed over from Sri Lanka to Thailand for the next BIMSTEC gathering. Other member states include Bangladesh, Bhutan, Myanmar, and Nepal.

title: Victoria approves Delburn wind power farm in Australia
content:
**April 1, 2022**

Victorian planning minister Richard Wynne approved a proposal for a 33-turbine wind farm in a pine tree plantation near Delburn, Gippsland, on March 27. The approval was first reported late Tuesday. Plans for a battery energy storage system have been suspended due to fire safety concerns. Scheduled for construction by OSMI Australia Pty in 2023, this wind farm will become the first of its kind built in a plantation in Victoria.

In late 2021, a planning panel reviewed testimony from local residents, community groups, and OSMI representatives. The panel subsequently recommended approval in a comprehensive 224-page report but noted that information regarding the siting and fire safety measures for the battery energy storage system was inadequate for endorsement at this stage.

OSMI executive director Peter Marriott emphasized that the battery energy storage system is "certainly not a key part of the project" but expressed a willingness to explore its potential, highlighting their interest in the findings from the CFA and WorkSafe investigation into the Moorabool battery fire.

In response to the decision, Nationals member for Gippsland South Danny O'Brien pointed to a recent court ruling halting nighttime noise emissions from a Tarwin Lower wind farm, questioning how the Minister could approve the Delburn project shortly thereafter, especially in light of local opposition. O'Brien advocated for offshore wind farm locations, expressing support for proposed initiatives like the Star of the South.

On a positive note, community group Voices of the Valley, formed after the 2014 Hazelwood mine fire, welcomed the approval. President Wendy Farmer remarked on the region's energy transformation, stating, "Power stations have dominated the landscape over the past century in the valley, but now we are witnessing a shift in energy across the region." She also noted that the approval coincides with the fifth anniversary of the Hazelwood power station's closure.

title: Federal judge rejects hate crime plea in Arbery killing
content:
**Thursday, February 3, 2022**

On Monday, Judge Lisa Godbey Wood of the U.S. District Court in Brunswick, Georgia, rejected a guilty plea from Travis McMichael, who had offered to plead guilty to federal hate crimes in the death of Ahmaud Arbery. It is rare for a U.S. judge to turn down a plea agreement that would have waived McMichael's right to appeal.

McMichael expressed his willingness to plead guilty to attacking Arbery out of racial animosity, which would categorize Arbery's murder as a hate crime. Under the proposed plea deal, McMichael would have served the first 30 years of his sentence in federal prison, followed by a transfer to a Georgia state prison for the remainder of his life. Even if his state charges were later overturned, he would still face many years behind bars.

In court, federal prosecutors encouraged Judge Wood to accept the plea deal, but Arbery's family opposed it. Wanda Cooper-Jones, Arbery's mother, stated that allowing the men who killed her son to choose their confinement would be a betrayal: "Granting these men their preferred choice of confinement would defeat me. It gives them one last chance to spit in my face."

Prosecutors asserted that they had consulted with the victim's family regarding the plea deal beforehand, a claim disputed by Cooper-Jones' legal team. 

Judge Wood indicated that Cooper-Jones' statement influenced her decision, but the primary reason for her rejection was her desire to avoid being restricted to the 30-year sentence proposed by the prosecution and McMichael's defense.

This decision raises uncertainty about whether Gregory McMichael, Travis's father and also implicated in Arbery's death, will proceed with a planned guilty plea. 

In February 2020, the McMichaels and a third man, William Bryan, pursued Arbery, 25, in trucks as he jogged through their suburban Georgia neighborhood. Travis McMichael confronted Arbery on foot and shot him. Bryan recorded a cellphone video of the incident, which later circulated online.

In November 2021, all three men were convicted of murder in Glynn County Superior Court, receiving life sentences, although only Bryan was eligible for parole. At that time, Georgia lacked its own hate crime statute, prompting prosecutors to pursue federal charges against the men.

Jury selection for Travis McMichael's federal hate crimes trial is set to begin on Monday, February 7.

title: Russia and China sign major gas pipeline deal for 30 years
content:
**Saturday, February 5, 2022**

On Friday, Russia finalized a 30-year agreement to supply gas to China, further solidifying the energy partnership between the two nations. President Putin met with his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, where they discussed plans to boost trade exports from the Russian Far East to China. This meeting coincided with Putin's visit to China for the 2022 Winter Olympics.

Under the new agreement, Russia aims to increase its gas exports to China by 10 billion cubic meters annually, bringing the total supply to 48 billion cubic meters per year. The project is valued at an estimated USD 117.5 billion. Russian energy firm Gazprom will play a key role in the deal, supplying gas to China National Petroleum Corporation. Gazprom announced that the project is expected to commence within two to three years.

President Putin expressed his optimism regarding the agreement, stating that "a step forward was made in the gas industry." Russia currently exports liquefied natural gas to China through the Power of Siberia pipeline. Notably, the deal will be conducted in Euros, reflecting both countries' efforts to reduce their reliance on the US dollar for foreign trade.

title: US attorney Michael Avenatti found guilty of stealing from client
content:
**Saturday, February 5, 2022**

Former lawyer Michael Avenatti was convicted yesterday of wire fraud and identity theft for stealing hundreds of thousands of dollars from Stormy Daniels, an adult film actor who was working on a book in 2018 about her alleged affair with then-President Donald Trump. 

Testimony revealed that Avenatti persuaded Daniels' agent to redirect payments from her book publisher to an account he controlled, without her knowledge. 

He was found guilty by a jury in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, located in Manhattan, where he represented himself. Sentencing is set for May 24. Avenatti had previously been convicted in 2020 for attempting to extort millions from sports brand Nike.

title: Russia threatens Wikipedia with 4 million ruble fine for coverage of war in Ukraine
content:
**Saturday, April 2, 2022**  

On Thursday, Roskomnadzor, the Russian government's communications agency, issued a warning of a potential fine of 4 million rubles (approximately US$47,000) against Wikipedia unless it removes information regarding the war in Ukraine from its article on the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine.  

Roskomnadzor condemned the content as "unreliable socially significant materials, as well as other prohibited information," accusing Wikipedia of intentionally misleading the Russian populace, though it did not specify which particular details it wanted deleted. Guidelines introduced by the Russian government last month prohibit the use of terms such as "war" to describe the conflict. Consequently, many independent news agencies and journalists have either closed down or fled the country.  

In a previous warning, Roskomnadzor stated that Wikipedia included "inaccurate information about the special military operation to protect the Donetsk and Luhansk People's Republics for the de-militarization and de-Nazification of Ukraine." Wikipedia, however, disputes these claims, labeling them as unsupported by evidence, and provides information on both Ukrainian civilian and Russian military casualties.  

A spokesperson for the Wikimedia Foundation informed the press that the Russian government had requested changes on two occasions, March 1 and March 29. The spokesperson emphasized, "The Wikimedia Foundation supports everyone's fundamental right to access free, open, and verifiable information; this escalation does not change our commitment."  

In response to earlier requests, the Foundation had denounced the demands as "threatening censorship," stating that removing the information could result in "life-altering consequences" for those who would be denied access to it. According to the Wikimedia Foundation, the English Wikipedia page addressing the war had garnered 11 million views as of March 8 and is available in 99 other languages.

title: 30,000-year-old Austrian statue traced to stone from Italy
content:
**Revised Version:**

**March 5, 2022**

In a study published on Monday in *Scientific Reports*, researchers from the University of Vienna and the Vienna Natural History Museum revealed that the stone used to carve the Venus of Willendorf originated from northern Italy, located hundreds of miles away from where the sculpture was found, across the Alps.

Dating back 30,000 years, the Venus of Willendorf is among the oldest known examples of human art, standing at approximately 4.3 inches (11 cm) tall. Like many prehistoric statuettes, it depicts a female figure characterized by pronounced physical features such as a large stomach and prominent breasts. Unlike most similar artifacts, which were typically carved from ivory or bone, the Venus is crafted from oolite, a type of limestone. Researchers believe it was created by the Gravettian culture, likely using flint tools. The sculpture is named after Venus, the Roman goddess of love.

To determine the origins of the stone, scientists compared rock samples from locations as far west as France and as far east as Ukraine with microscopic analyses of the Venus. Oolite, a sedimentary rock formed by layers of silt and other materials, allows for the identification of individual grains and shell fragments. Notably, one tiny shell fragment in the Venus came from a creature that lived during the Jurassic period, although the stone was harvested and shaped much later.

Unlike previous assessments that focused solely on the exterior, this study utilized computed tomography to examine the interior of the statue without causing damage. The scan revealed that the stone bore little resemblance to oolites found near Willendorf, but closely matched those from Lake Garda in Italy, over 350 miles (563 km) away, on the other side of the Alps and the Danube River. A potential but less likely source of the stone could be in Ukraine, situated over 1,600 kilometers (994 miles) east of where the statue was discovered in Wachau, Austria, in 1908.

Lead author Gerhard Weber speculated that the stone could have been transported during human migration: "When the climate or prey situation changed, [people] moved on, preferably along rivers," he noted.

The researchers suggest that these findings offer new insights into the travel patterns of prehistoric humans in and around the Alpine region. The study received funding from the state of Lower Austria.

title: Tonga enters lockdown after detecting new COVID-19 cases
content:
**Wednesday, February 2, 2022**

Tongan Prime Minister Siaosi Sovaleni announced yesterday that the country would enter a lockdown effective today following the detection of two COVID-19 cases among workers managing foreign aid in the capital, Nuku'alofa. Additionally, three more cases were identified among the family members of the port workers. Until now, the island nation had reported only one prior case of the virus.

In his address, Sovaleni emphasized that the lockdown was essential to "slow down and stop those who have been affected." He also halted all boat and aircraft services between the islands to curb further viral spread.

Tonga has been receiving foreign aid from various nations in the wake of the recent Hunga Tonga volcanic eruption and tsunami. Tongan authorities have implemented a strict "no-contact" policy for handling foreign aid.

title: Mass protests prompt Sri Lankan cabinet to resign
content:
**Sri Lanka's Cabinet Resigns Amid Economic Crisis**

On Monday, the Sri Lankan cabinet, comprising 26 ministers, resigned, leaving President Gotabaya Rajapaksa and Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa in their positions as the government faced mounting public discontent over the ongoing economic crisis. 

Prior to the resignations, President Rajapaksa had called for all political parties to come together to form a national unity government. However, this proposal was rejected by two major political parties, the Samagi Jana Balavegaya (SJB) and the Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna (JVP), who demanded the president's resignation.

In the wake of the cabinet's resignation, Ajith Nivard Cabraal, the Governor of the Central Bank of Sri Lanka, also announced his resignation. 

The economic turmoil prompted the government to halt imports in March 2020 in a bid to conserve foreign exchange reserves. By February, Sri Lanka's reserves had dwindled to approximately USD 2 billion, down 70% over the past two years. The country requires USD 7 billion this year to manage its total debt of USD 51 billion.

Recently, Sri Lanka has struggled with severe fuel shortages, particularly of diesel, resulting in protests and empty fuel stations. 

In March, the inflation rate in Sri Lanka surged to 18.7%, while food prices skyrocketed by 30.1%. The Sri Lankan rupee has also suffered, losing 30% of its value against the US dollar since a recent devaluation as the government engages in discussions with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) for a potential bailout.

title: Proud Boys chapter leader pleads guilty in US Capitol attack
content:
**Sunday, April 10, 2022**

On Friday, Charles Donohoe, leader of the North Carolina chapter of the Proud Boys, pleaded guilty to conspiracy to obstruct Congress and assaulting a law enforcement officer, both felonies, related to the January 6, 2021, Capitol attack. 

As part of a plea deal, Donohoe agreed to cooperate with federal prosecutors in their investigations into the Proud Boys and its leadership. Other prominent members, including national chairman Enrique Tarrio, have pleaded not guilty to charges of seditious conspiracy. Prosecutors allege that they were part of an elite group known as the "Ministry of Self Defense," which was specifically chosen by Tarrio.

Court filings revealed that Donohoe provided the Proud Boys with radio transmitters to facilitate communication before and during the Capitol riot. Tarrio was arrested two days prior to the attack. Following Tarrio's arrest, Donohoe deleted group messages from the Telegram platform and expressed concerns that their plans might be compromised, stating, "Well at least they won't get our boots on the ground plan because we are one step ahead of them."

Although Donohoe did not enter the Capitol, having been affected by pepper spray during the initial charge, he faces assault charges for allegedly throwing two water bottles at Capitol Police officers. Additionally, he reportedly sent messages indicating, "We stormed the Capitol unarmed… we took it over."

The Capitol assault occurred while Congress was certifying the result

title: Lost Antarctic shipwreck from 1915 Shackleton expedition, Endurance, rediscovered
content:
**Thursday, March 10, 2022**

The remains of the Endurance, the ship from Sir Ernest Shackleton's 1915 expedition to Antarctica, were rediscovered beneath Antarctic waters on March 7, as announced yesterday. This discovery by the Endurance22 expedition comes over a century after the vessel was trapped by sea ice off the Antarctic coast and subsequently sank to the bottom of the Weddell Sea.

Remarkably, the ship appears to be in excellent condition, preserved by the cold waters. The timbers look intact, and the name Endurance is clearly visible below the stern, alongside the five-pointed star Polaris, both unchanged despite the passage of time.

Submersible craft deployed by Endurance22, which was formed and funded by the Falklands Maritime Heritage Trust, captured images of the Endurance at a depth of approximately 3,008 meters (9,868.8 ft). These vehicles were launched from the expedition's main vessel, the South African icebreaker S.A. Agulhas II.

The Endurance was the flagship of the Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition, which aimed to achieve the first land crossing of Antarctica. Sir Ernest Shackleton, a pioneer in British Antarctic exploration during the early 20th century, and his crew became stranded when the ship became trapped in sea ice and was gradually crushed. They camped on the ice until they were able to launch lifeboats and ultimately reach safety. Fortunately, all members of the expedition survived, though the Endurance sank.

For many years, locating the ship's remains had been nearly impossible due to the thick sea ice that covers the Weddell Sea year-round. However, the past month recorded the lowest levels of Antarctic sea ice since the inception of satellite monitoring, enabling the multinational team assembled by the Falklands Maritime Heritage Trust to make this significant discovery.

Expedition leader Dr. John Shears remarked on the successful expedition, stating: "We have made polar history... and successfully completed the world's most challenging shipwreck search." He emphasized the accomplishments of humanity when working together in overcoming obstacles.

Menson Bound, the director of exploration, added: "It is not just about the past; we are bringing the story of Shackleton and the Endurance to new audiences, especially the next generation, who will be responsible for safeguarding our polar regions and our planet. We hope our discovery will inspire young people with the pioneering spirit, courage, and fortitude of those who sailed the Endurance to Antarctica."

title: Ballarat candidates debate climate at election forum
content:
**Sunday, May 8, 2022**  

**Ballarat, Australia** — In the lead-up to the upcoming Australian federal election, four candidates vying for the Division of Ballarat gathered last Sunday at the Ballarat Tech School for a climate-focused forum organized by the local group Ballarat Renewable Energy and Zero Emissions (BREAZE).  

Present were sitting Labor MP Catherine King, Greens candidate and former mayor John Barnes, Australian Federation Party candidate Kerryn Sedgman, and independent candidate Alex Graham. Local Liberal and Liberal Democrats candidates sent their apologies for not attending.  

The event kicked off with a climate action rally outside the Ballarat Civics Hall and Town Hall, featuring speeches from representatives of BREAZE, Extinction Rebellion, Environment Victoria, the Public Transport Users Association, and Ballarat Trades Hall.  

The forum commenced with candidates each delivering a three-minute summary of their climate policies before fielding questions from the public. Barnes asserted that "the Greens have the most ambitious program of any party on addressing climate change" and indicated that if the Greens held the balance of power, they would push Labor towards "the reforming zeal of past generations," referencing former Labor Prime Minister Gough Whitlam. He emphasized the Greens' target of a 75% emissions reduction by 2030 and a commitment to end coal mining, burning, and exports within the same timeframe.  

Independent candidate Alex Graham expressed his passion for the environment, claiming to offer "the best policy." He proposed a referendum that would enable the Australian government to "write its own money supply into existence," suggesting this would provide "money beyond the pale to totally restore our environment."  

Incumbent MP Catherine King reflected on her two decades in Parliament, noting a lack of progress on climate issues. She pointed to the previous Labor government's unsuccessful attempts to legislate climate policies, such as the Carbon Pollution Reduction Scheme (CPRS), which she claimed were "completely and utterly dismantled" after the 2013 election.  

King highlighted Labor's Powering Australia policy announced in December 2021, stating it enjoys support from groups including the Business Council of Australia, National Farmers' Federation, and various environmental organizations. The policy outlines a commitment to achieving a 43% emissions reduction by 2030 and net-zero carbon emissions by 2050 while focusing on job growth and increased renewable energy.  

Kerryn Sedgman of the Australian Federation Party promised to prioritize community perspectives, reading directly from the Federation's climate policy: "carbon is not the enemy. Toxic pesticides are the true enemy." She argued that pesticides are the primary source of nitrous oxide (N₂O), which is "300 times worse than carbon."  

Following the candidates’ opening statements, the public was invited to ask questions. The first question requested the candidates' top two priorities for climate action. Barnes identified "prompt action" and transforming the economy towards sustainability as priorities, while Graham suggested a limitless supply of money could eradicate climate issues and enhance Australia’s model for the world. He indicated his priorities would be increasing funding and introducing new technologies.  

King prioritized expanding renewable energy in the grid and noted her intention to integrate a climate section within the Transport and Infrastructure Department, along with plans to establish a network of electric vehicle charging stations. Sedgman emphasized that soil regeneration was vital for carbon sequestration and advocated for immediate educational efforts and community engagement on climate issues.  

The event was momentarily disrupted by an attendee questioning a vague "ninety-year suppression order" related to alleged paedophiles, which was dismissed by organizers. King labeled it a "QAnon conspiracy theory."  

The discussion then shifted to the proposed Western Victorian Transmission Network, an overhead line from Bulgana to Sydenham. Graham suggested his referendum could lead to federal subsidies for underground transmission lines beneath the Western Highway, asserting that financial interests should not interfere with environmental protection. King highlighted concerns about the proposed transfer station's location and indicated that regulatory processes required reform.  

Sedgman admitted to her limited knowledge of the background King referred to and expressed a desire to engage with those affected. Barnes criticized AusNet's consultation process regarding the transmission line and hoped an extended timeline for the environmental impact statement would allow for better community input. He also noted that AusNet had claimed underground construction would be thirteen times more expensive than overhead alternatives, a figure contradicted by a study from the Shire of Moorabool, which found it would only be five times more costly.  

Candidates were queried about their stance on innovations like direct air capture. Barnes asserted, "the best way to sequester carbon is not to release it in the first place," deeming mechanical carbon removal a "pipe dream." Graham humorously remarked he would consult a friend who might be able to achieve it. King noted that while such technology is still developing, A$3 billion is earmarked in Labor's Powering Australia plan for advancing new emission-reducing technologies. Sedgman highlighted the urgent need to address deforestation rates.  

When asked about committing to no new coal and gas infrastructure, King confirmed that a moratorium on such developments is not part of Labor's policy, although she asserted the party would refrain from investing taxpayer funds in them. Graham, with a background in the industry, pledged to phase out every coal-fired power station as swiftly as possible and prohibit new coal plants. He also vowed to shut down coal mines and ban fracking.  

Barnes reiterated the Greens' commitment to heeding the International Energy Agency's advice, vowing to prevent new coal, gas, or oil projects and to close all coal-fired power stations by 2030, substituting them with renewable energy sources. He emphasized the necessity of reducing emissions before the global temperature rises by 1.5 °C.  

One audience member posed a hypothetical about how candidates would respond if, after the election, Labor achieved a clear majority versus if the Greens held the balance of power. King pointed out that the "beauty of power in Australia" is the non-requirement for legislation, but emphasized Labor's commitment to pursuing 43% emissions reduction and net-zero emissions by 2050. Barnes affirmed the Greens would advocate for more ambitious targets if they were in the balance.  

The candidates were also asked about Beyond Zero Emissions' proposal to transform northern Australia into the "battery of Asia." Barnes portrayed Australia as a potential "energy superpower," noting that effective government policy could drive market support. King claimed Labor's Powering Australia plan could generate over 600,000 jobs and echoed the sentiment that Australia should strive to be a renewable energy superpower and lead technology exports.  

The final question addressed the potential job losses from transitioning to renewable energy in coal-dependent communities like the Hunter Valley. Graham called for a "basic, living universal wage," while Sedgman questioned who would qualify for new jobs under existing mandates. King referred to diminishing demand for fossil fuels, asserting the importance of preparing workers for the inevitable transition to rewarding renewable jobs. Barnes outlined the Greens' proposal to allocate A$19 billion over ten years to aid communities impacted by the transition away from fossil fuels, emphasizing the importance of retraining programs and maintaining existing incomes for a decade if workers struggle to find equally lucrative positions. He underscored that it is crucial to support mining communities with dignity.  

The forum concluded with representatives from Environment Victoria presenting an open letter, signed by 125 individuals, calling for "faster and fairer climate action." The letter advocated for a replacement of "coal, oil, and gas with clean energy," a national plan to significantly reduce climate pollution this decade with strict targets, and an expedited rollout of renewable energy projects aimed at creating a "healthy, prosperous economy while ceasing any new fossil fuel energy generation projects."

title: Indian singer Lata Mangeshkar dies at age 92
content:
**Tuesday, February 8, 2022**

Indian singer Lata Mangeshkar passed away on Sunday at the age of 92 due to multi-organ failure at Breach Candy Hospital in Mumbai. She had been hospitalized after testing positive for COVID-19 on January 11.

Affectionately known as the 'Nightingale of Bollywood', Mangeshkar was awarded India's highest civilian honor, the Bharat Ratna, in 2001. In 2007, she received France’s highest civilian award, the Legion of Honour.

In her memory, the Government of India declared two days of national mourning, starting Sunday, during which the national flag was flown at half-mast across the country. Mangeshkar was given a state funeral in Mumbai on the same day.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi expressed that Mangeshkar has left "a void in our nation that cannot be filled," while President Ram Nath Kovind described the news as "heartbreaking for me, as it is for millions the world over," extending his condolences. Members of the Indian national cricket team wore black armbands during the India vs West Indies 1st One Day International match in tribute to Mangeshkar.

Pakistani Minister for Information and Broadcasting Fawad Chaudhry also expressed his sorrow over her passing. Prime Minister of Bangladesh Sheikh Hasina sent a condolence letter to Modi, stating that "the people of Bangladesh mourn in solidarity with the people of India in this hour of grief."

title: Gunman kills three, wounds several others in Tel Aviv, Israel
content:
**Saturday, April 9, 2022**

On Thursday evening, a gunman killed three people and injured at least nine others in an entertainment district of Tel Aviv, Israel, before being located and shot dead by security forces early Friday morning. 

Magen David Adom, the national emergency medical service, reported receiving the first call about the incident at 21:00 IST (1900 UTC). The victims were taken to three different hospitals, where two men were pronounced dead at the scene and another succumbed to his injuries later. Three individuals are in serious condition, while four others sustained minor injuries. 

The shootings began at a pub on Dizengoff Street, where five victims were initially reported. Additional shootings occurred on J. L. Gordon Street and in nearby areas. Security forces from Shin Bet killed the alleged gunman after a shootout near a mosque in the southern Tel Aviv neighborhood of Jaffa. The suspect has been identified as a 29-year-old Palestinian man from Jenin, a city in northern West Bank.

Prime Minister Naftali Bennett, speaking at HaKirya on Friday, extended his condolences to the families of those killed and expressed hopes for the swift recovery of the injured. He noted that the perpetrator was not affiliated with any organization but had received assistance and weapons. "Those who aid and abet terrorists must understand that the consequences of their actions will be severe," he stated. Bennett also described celebrations in Jenin following news of the attack, highlighting instances of incitement to violence from the terrorist's family. "As a nation and a state, we will need patience, resilience, and heightened vigilance," he added. "Above all, we must maintain our belief in the justice of our cause in this land."

U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken issued a statement saying, "We are closely monitoring developments and will remain in regular contact with our Israeli partners, standing firm against senseless terrorism and violence." 

March saw a surge in attacks in Israel, including a shooting in Bnei Brak, just east of Tel Aviv, which resulted in five fatalities.

title: US Senate confirms Ketanji Brown Jackson for Supreme Court
content:
**Thursday, April 9, 2022**

On Thursday, the United States Senate confirmed Ketanji Brown Jackson as an associate justice of the Supreme Court, making her the first African American woman to serve on the Court. 

The final vote was 53 in favor and 47 against, primarily divided along party lines between Democrats and Republicans. Notably, three Republican senators—Susan Collins (Maine), Mitt Romney (Utah), and Lisa Murkowski (Alaska)—broke with their party to support Jackson. Vice President Kamala Harris presided over the vote and would have cast a tiebreaking vote if necessary.

Jackson and President Joe Biden observed the proceedings from the Roosevelt Room of the White House. Biden nominated Jackson on February 25 to succeed retiring Justice Stephen Breyer. During his presidential campaign in 2020, Biden pledged to nominate an African American woman to the Supreme Court. Senate confirmation is required for all presidential nominations. 

On March 21, Jackson was introduced to the Senate by Thomas B. Griffith, a former judge on the D.C. Court of Appeals. In her opening remarks, she stated, "My parents taught me that, unlike the many barriers they faced growing up, my path was clearer. If I worked hard and believed in myself, I could do anything or be anything I wanted to be." She concluded her remarks by committing to support and defend the Constitution and American democracy should she be confirmed.

During the second day of confirmation hearings, Senator Josh Hawley (Republican; Missouri) questioned Jackson regarding her handling of child pornography cases, specifically referencing a three-month prison sentence she imposed in United States v. Hawkins, despite a two-year sentence being sought by prosecutors and Federal Sentencing Guidelines recommending eight years. Jackson defended her decisions, arguing that the guidelines fail to differentiate among defendants and need reform. She emphasized, "Congress has given judges the discretion to make individualized decisions based on various factors, including the age and circumstances of the defendant." In this case, the defendant was eighteen years old. 

On the third day, Jackson was asked about applying Constitutional provisions crafted over two centuries ago to contemporary issues. She explained, "It's a process of understanding the core foundational principles of the Constitution as originally intended and applying those principles to modern-day situations." 

Senators Lindsey Graham (Republican; South Carolina) and Ted Cruz (Republican; Texas) continued their questioning regarding light sentences, leading Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Dick Durbin (Democrat; Illinois) to intervene frequently on Jackson's behalf. While Durbin noted the interruptions, he was accused of filibustering in favor of the nominee.

On the final day of the hearings, March 24, Durbin announced that the Judiciary Committee would convene on March 28, potentially setting the stage for a vote on Jackson for April 4. Jackson was absent that day as the Senate heard testimony from other witnesses, including Wade Henderson, president of the Leadership Conference on Civil and Human Rights, who praised Jackson's extraordinary background and legal expertise.

Senator Marsha Blackburn (Republican; Tennessee) sought access to confidential pre-sentencing reports from Jackson's previous child pornography cases, reports that are protected to safeguard victims. Durbin denied her request, stating, "I would not want that on my conscience, that we did this for some political exercise, which I think is totally unnecessary, and someone was harmed as a result of it. I'm going to resist it every step of the way."

On April 4, the Judiciary Committee voted 11-11 on Jackson's nomination, resulting in a deadlock that Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer (New York) later broke with a vote, sending it to the Senate floor.

Before her nomination, Jackson held several significant positions, including clerk for Breyer, federal public defender, federal district court judge, member of the sentencing commission, and attorney in private practice. The Supreme Court is composed of eight associate justices and one chief justice.

title: United States bans importation of Russian fossil fuels
content:
**Wednesday, March 9, 2022**

On Tuesday, President Joe Biden announced a ban on imports of oil, gas, and coal from Russia in response to the Russian invasion of Ukraine that began last month. Biden stated, "The United States is targeting the main artery of Russia's economy," while recognizing that many allied nations may not be able to implement similar bans.

"The decision today is not without cost here at home," Biden added. "Putin's war is already impacting American families at the gas pump. Since the onset of Putin's military build-up at the Ukrainian borders, gas prices in the U.S. have surged by 75 cents, and this action will likely lead to further increases. I will do everything in my power to mitigate Putin's price hike here at home."

European countries depend more heavily on fuel imports from Russia compared to the United States. Throughout his announcement, Biden consistently referred to the invasion as Vladimir Putin's war.

title: Entomological Society of America renames invasive moth
content:
**Tuesday, March 8, 2022**

On Wednesday, the Entomological Society of America officially renamed the caterpillar previously known as the "gypsy moth" to "spongy moth," as part of its Better Common Names Project. Its scientific name remains Lymantria dispar.

The society announced the decision to remove the former name last July, but it was not until last week that the name "spongy moth" was unanimously chosen. Magda Matache, a Romani scholar from Harvard University's Roma Program, stated, "Gypsy is considered a racial slur by many Romani people. It carries a very painful history, and it is offensive." The Romani, or Roma, have faced significant prejudice in both Europe and North America.

The 57 members of the Project who worked on this species reviewed public comments and evaluated over 200 suggested names. The name "spongy moth," derived from the French "spongieuse," was proposed in January. The term "spongy" describes the sponge-like appearance of the egg masses that protect the animal's eggs throughout winter. This new name also aligns with its common names in other languages, such as "sponge-spinner" in German and "sponge-knitter" in Turkish. According to CNN, the species is most likely to spread to new areas during its egg stage, as they can be transported on firewood or vehicles.

Native to Europe, Asia, and northern Africa, the spongy moth is a highly destructive invasive species in North America, having first arrived on the continent in 1869. The caterpillars are brown, covered in spines, and feature blue and red spots. They can completely defoliate trees, with spongy moth caterpillars having stripped 1 million acres of North American forests annually since 1980. 

"They essentially behave like The Very Hungry Caterpillar, consuming everything in their path in deciduous forests," said Jessica Ware of the Entomological Society of America, referencing the popular children's book. "'Spongy moth' is already starting to appear in media stories and other online resources, which we're excited about. However, we recognize that this name change won't be immediate," she added. 

"Particularly in printed materials or regulations related to L. dispar, it will take time to phase in the use of the new name. The ESA will continue to provide resources to support organizations in adopting this change." 

The Entomological Society of America is the world's largest professional organization for insect scientists.

title: Financial Action Task Force places United Arab Emirates on money laundering 'grey' list
content:
**Tuesday, March 8, 2022**

On March 4, the Financial Action Task Force (FATF) placed the United Arab Emirates on its global grey list due to "strategic deficiencies" in its efforts to combat "money laundering, terrorist financing, and proliferation financing," subjecting it to increased scrutiny. The UAE joins 23 other countries on the list, including regional neighbors Jordan, Syria, Yemen, as well as Pakistan and Turkey, with all actively cooperating with the FATF. While a grey listing is less severe than a 'black' listing—which includes Iran and North Korea—it may harm the UAE's reputation as a business-friendly destination.

The grey listing could lead to unfavorable rate adjustments, increased transaction costs, and stiffer competition with fellow Gulf state Saudi Arabia. A report from the International Monetary Fund published in May 2021 indicated that grey-listing typically results in an average negative impact of 7.6% on a country's GDP, amounting to approximately USD 27.3 billion based on the UAE's 2020 GDP figures.

According to the Paris-based FATF, being grey-listed signifies that the country is committed to swiftly addressing the identified strategic deficiencies. A follow-up evaluation in November 2021 noted progress in four key areas, with the UAE deemed "compliant" or "highly compliant" with 36 out of 40 recommendations. Since passing a federal decree on money laundering in 2018 to align with international standards, the UAE has established four specialized courts for prosecutions. Additionally, in December 2020, it formed an Executive Office focused on combating money laundering and terrorist financing. Nevertheless, the FATF has called for improvements in risk management in specific sectors and enhancement of both domestic and international investigations into money laundering.

In response, the Executive Office stated: "The UAE will continue its ongoing efforts to identify, disrupt, and penalize criminals and illicit financial networks, in alignment with FATF's findings and the UAE’s National Action Plan." The Office also emphasized its commitment to "close coordination with our international partners." Former UAE Foreign Affairs Minister Anwar Gargash tweeted that the UAE remains "resolute in strengthening strategic cooperation with our partners to address this global challenge."

Katherine Bauer, a senior fellow at The Washington Institute for Near East Policy, criticized the UAE's "inherent vulnerabilities to illicit finance" arising from its position as a regional commercial and financial hub, noting that the necessary changes will not occur overnight. The UAE was implicated in the Panama Papers leak in 2016 as "home to a thriving trade in financial secrecy," according to the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists (ICIJ), which implicated numerous Emirati officials in questionable activities, including Prime Minister Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum's connection to a cybersecurity firm alleged to be involved in espionage.

The ICIJ described the UAE as "a center for financial crime," highlighting that "mass surveillance and the monarchy's firm grip on the courts and media make it difficult to challenge the system or expose suspect business dealings." Jodi Vittori, a fellow at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, remarked that "the U.S. seems to have turned a blind eye to [the UAE's] role in facilitating illicit finance, conflict minerals, and organized crime."

The decision to grey-list the UAE was made during the FATF's sixth plenary session, held under a German presidency from March 2 to 4. During the same session, Zimbabwe was removed from increased monitoring, while France was recognized for having a "robust and sophisticated" financial framework, albeit with areas for improvement.

title: Australian cricketer Shane Warne dies aged 52
content:
Date: March 7, 2022 

Australian cricket legend Shane Warne passed away at the age of 52 from a suspected heart attack on Friday in a villa on the island of Ko Samui, Thailand.

His death occurred just hours after the passing of fellow Australian cricket player Rod Marsh, to whom Warne had paid tribute on Twitter shortly before his own demise. Warne's management confirmed in a statement to Fox Sports, "Shane was found unresponsive in his villa, and despite the best efforts of medical personnel, he could not be revived."

Tributes poured in from former and current cricketers in Australia and around the globe, including Adam Gilchrist, India's Virat Kohli and Sachin Tendulkar, and Pakistan's Muhammad Rizwan, among many others. 

Warne's former fiancée, Elizabeth Hurley, expressed her sorrow, saying, "I feel like the sun has gone behind a cloud forever. RIP, my beloved lionheart." 

Fans honored Warne's memory by decorating his statue outside the Melbourne Cricket Ground with personal items such as flowers, beer cans, baked beans, meat pies, and cigarettes. In tribute, the MCG announced that the Great Southern Stand would be renamed the S.K. Warne Stand.

Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews extended an offer of a state funeral to Warne's family, which they accepted. Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison also expressed condolences and announced that the federal government would support the state funeral.

As of now, the date and location of the funeral have not been publicly disclosed.

title: Grand Finals set in 2021-22 Sunshine Coast, Australia cricket season
content:
**Cricket Grand Final Matchups Set on Australia's Sunshine Coast Amid Washouts**

Monday, March 7, 2022  

The matchups for the Cricket Grand Final on Australia's Sunshine Coast have been finalized, primarily due to several washed-out semi-finals.  

Three scheduled games at Burpengary, Morayfield, and Wamuran could not be played after access to local sporting grounds was closed by the Moreton Bay Council. The affected matches included the Division 3 clash between Burpengary and USC, the Division 1 encounter between Caboolture and Maroochydore, and the Division 4 showdown between Wamuran-Stanley River and Palmwoods.  

No play was possible at the Glasshouse Mountains grounds either, as the sports club managing the facilities denied access. The Division 4 match between Glasshouse and Maroochydore, along with the Division 5 game between Glasshouse and USC, were also impacted.  

One game did proceed in Palmwoods, where the Division 5 match between Palmwoods and Cooroy-Eumundi at Palmwoods Sports Reserve almost yielded a first innings result on day one. The home team batted first, scoring 92 runs, while Cooroy reached 52 for the loss of 9 wickets before Palmwoods secured the final wicket on Sunday.  

In Tewantin, the main ground at Read Park was ruled too waterlogged after an inspection by both teams ahead of the Division 1 match between Tewantin Noosa and Glasshouse. Tewantin's Division 6 side managed to play 61 overs against Yandina on Sunday before lightning forced a halt, and that match ended in a draw.  

USC and Palmwoods achieved enough play for a first innings result. The home side chased down the required 86 runs an hour before the scheduled lunch break, with Palmwoods conceding the match about 20 minutes before the interval.  

USC all-rounder George Bagshaw commented, "We bowled well, getting them out for about 86, and then we did the rest with the bat. [We] certainly dug in; Trav[is Bell] and I put on a good partnership, and it was great for the rest of the boys to finish it off this morning."

title: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un oversees hypersonic missile test
content:
**Revised News Article:**

**Friday, January 14, 2022**

On January 12, the North Korean state-run newspaper Rodong Sinmun reported on a hypersonic missile launch that took place on Tuesday, attended by leader Kim Jong-un along with senior officials Jo Yong Won and Kim Yo-jong. This marks North Korea's third missile launch of the year, with state media claiming it flew approximately 1,000 kilometers (621 miles) before crashing into the sea.

The missile, described as "the Juche weapon representing the power of the DPRK" and possessing "superior maneuverability," was test-fired for "final verification of overall technical specifications," according to state reports. However, in an email to Al Jazeera, Professor Leif-Eric Easley from Ewha University in Seoul stated that the "so-called hypersonic weapon is not technologically ready." Initially, South Korean military authorities downplayed the missile's significance, but later assessments indicated it demonstrated "improvement," as reported by the Yonhap News Agency.

Earlier this year, North Korea conducted two missile tests: one on the previous Wednesday and another on Monday, both confirmed by South Korea and the Japanese coast guard. The first launch was described by state media as a winter resilience test. North Korea had previously tested its first hypersonic missile, the Hwasong-8, on September 28. Defense expert Ankit Panda from the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace indicated that last Wednesday's missile was not the Hwasong-8 but rather a new model showcased at an October weapons exhibition in Pyongyang. Post-September test, Panda referred to the Hwasong-8 as a "significant milestone" in comments to the BBC.

On Monday, the United Nations (UN) missions of Albania, France, the Republic of Ireland, Japan, the United Kingdom, and the United States issued a joint call for dialogue and condemned the initial missile test. US Ambassador to the UN Linda Thomas-Greenfield labeled it "a significant threat to regional stability." On Tuesday, South Korean President Moon Jae-in expressed concerns regarding the tests, especially with the upcoming presidential election scheduled for March.

According to the BBC, hypersonic missiles are faster and have a longer capability to evade radar detection compared to traditional ballistic missiles.

title: Mass shooting takes place in New York City subway system
content:
On Tuesday, April 12, 2022, at approximately 8:30 a.m. New York Time (12:30 UTC), a mass shooting occurred on a train between the 25th Street Station and the 36th Street Station on the BMT Fourth Avenue Line of the New York City Subway in Sunset Park, Brooklyn.

At least sixteen people sustained injuries in the incident, with ten suffering gunshot wounds and six others injured by various means. According to a recent press briefing from the New York Police Department (NYPD) at the scene, there were no reported fatalities. Several individuals also received treatment for smoke inhalation and panic attacks.

Officials reported that the assailant ignited a smoke bomb while on the northbound N train and opened fire on commuters. When the train arrived at the 36th Street Station, injured passengers collapsed onto the platform. Preliminary investigations indicate that an additional smoke device was detonated at the station. The NYPD has confirmed that there are currently no explosive devices present at the scene.

The suspect, described as wearing a reflective vest and a gas mask, fled the area following the attack. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has since shut down several subway lines throughout Brooklyn. The Federal Bureau of Investigation has joined the inquiry into the incident.

President Joe Biden has been briefed about the situation, which comes amid an uptick in shootings in New York, according to NYPD data.

title: Metropolitan Police Commissioner Cressida Dick resigns amid criticism
content:
**Saturday, February 12, 2022**

Dame Cressida Dick, the Commissioner of the Metropolitan Police in London, resigned on Thursday after losing the support of Mayor Sadiq Khan. Her resignation came just hours after she told BBC Radio London that she had "absolutely no intention" of stepping down. In her farewell address, Dick stated that Khan "no longer has sufficient confidence in my leadership," indicating that the mayor had left her "no choice but to step aside."

Khan had placed Dick "on notice" on February 2, requiring her to implement reforms within the police service in response to a report on police conduct released the day before. The report from the Independent Office for Police Conduct (IOPC) highlighted "disgraceful" incidents of bullying, discrimination, misogyny, and sexual harassment within the force. Dick had previously weathered several scandals since 2019, including accusations of misleading the public over the inconclusive Operation Midland investigation, from which she was ultimately cleared.

Recent scrutiny has focused on claims of "institutional corruption" within the Met, a charge that Dick denies. This includes offensive remarks—racist, sexist, homophobic, and Islamophobic—made by some officers at Charing Cross railway station from 2016 to 2018. The February 1 report indicated that nine of fourteen officers investigated for sharing derogatory and sexist messages in private group chats continue to serve in the force, with two having been promoted to sergeant.

The Met also faced criticism for its sluggish investigation into "Partygate," a series of gatherings held at Downing Street in violation of Covid-19 restrictions. Sources have expressed disappointment within the Greater London Authority and the Home Office regarding the police's scandals, with some attributing these issues to Dick's defensiveness.

In a statement, Khan expressed dissatisfaction with Dick's response to his demands for necessary reforms aimed at rebuilding public trust in the Met. He underscored the urgency of addressing the racism, sexism, homophobia, bullying, and discrimination still present in the force. Following the report's release, an initial meeting with Dick was deemed inadequate, leading to her resignation before a subsequent meeting could take place.

Public discontent also arose over the Met's handling of Sarah Everard's murder, committed by former officer Wayne Couzens. Four individuals were arrested during a vigil for Everard last year for breaching Covid-19 restrictions. The Met gained further ridicule in October when it advised women concerned about an approaching officer to call 999 or engage with bystanders rather than seek immediate safety. This was part of a new strategy addressing sexual violence and the creation of a dedicated unit for tackling predatory offenders.

Both the Met and the government are conducting inquiries into the force’s handling of Everard's case, led by an independent review under Baroness Louise Casey. Additionally, in December, two constables were sentenced to 33 months in prison for sharing inappropriate photos of murdered sisters Bibaa Henry and Nicole Smallman, leading to accusations of racism and dehumanization from their mother, Mina Smallman.

In her earlier interview with Radio London, Dick insisted she would not resign, expressing her frustration with the February 1 report's findings. She maintained accountability and asserted the Met's capability, while acknowledging the damage to its reputation caused by "awful findings" alongside other recent distressing incidents.

While she claimed to have initiated a "real transformation" within the police force, she expressed that she was not complacent and warned of potential future incidents of embarrassment or disgrace in the ongoing efforts to eradicate misconduct. BBC correspondent Lauren Moss noted that Dick's resignation marked the first time she publicly acknowledged the issues.

Responses to Dick's departure were mixed. Former IOPC superintendent and Met officer Nursit Mehtab viewed her resignation as a necessary step to combat a "sub-culture" of sexism and racism within the force. Mehtab highlighted the damaging impact of the violent sentiments expressed in the communications of officers on public trust, especially among women and girls.

Alastair Morgan, whose brother Daniel was murdered, criticized Dick for bringing nothing but delays and disappointments to his family's pursuit of justice. Some activists echoed this sentiment, including groups like Reclaim These Streets and Sisters Uncut. Ricky Waumsley, whose partner was one of the victims of serial killer Stephen Port, expressed his approval of Dick's resignation, asserting accountability for the Met's failures.

Calls for substantial change within the police remain. Ruth Davidson of the charity Refuge emphasized that a leadership change alone does not resolve the ingrained misogyny within the institution, advocating for comprehensive reform across the UK. Mehtab reiterated that the issues at the Met cannot be dismissed as a few "bad apples," a term frequently used by the force in deflecting criticism. Journalist Robert Verkaik likened the current scandals to the 1970s Operation Countryman investigation, which led to numerous resignations and retirements among Met officers.

Nevertheless, Dick received support from Ken Marsh, chair of the Met Foundation, who argued that she should have been granted more time to rebuild public trust in the police. Khan, along with Home Secretary Priti Patel and Prime Minister Boris Johnson, expressed gratitude for Dick's service. Johnson, who is currently under investigation for his own role in Partygate, acknowledged Dick's dedicated service to the country.

Khan committed to collaborating closely with Patel to swiftly appoint a new commissioner to restore public trust in London’s police while ensuring safety. Dick will serve in a caretaker role until a successor is appointed. 

Having joined the force as a constable in 1983, Dick led the anti-gang Operation Trident in 2003 and was cleared of personal culpability in the investigation following the July 7, 2005 London bombings. She became the first female commissioner on February 22, 2017, after spending six years in the Foreign & Commonwealth Office, earning a salary of £230,000.

While Khan acknowledged Dick's achievements in combatting violent crime, the number of teenagers murdered in London reached its highest level in 2021 since 2008.

title: US warns its citizens to leave Ukraine as Russia could invade 'anytime'
content:
**February 12, 2022**

United States Secretary of State Antony Blinken issued a warning regarding the heightened tension between Russia and Ukraine, indicating that Russia's troop deployment near the Ukrainian border suggests an invasion could occur at any moment. In a press conference, Blinken advised all American citizens to evacuate Ukraine within 48 hours to mitigate the risks associated with a potential invasion. Australia and New Zealand have similarly urged their citizens to leave the Eastern European nation.

US President Joe Biden expressed concern in an NBC News interview on Thursday, stating that the situation in Ukraine "could escalate quickly." National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan further warned that American citizens choosing to remain in Ukraine should not expect military evacuation assistance, reiterating that a Russian invasion "could begin at any time."

While Russia has denied any plans to invade Ukraine, labeling the Western response as "a sign of diplomatic impoliteness and disrespect," satellite images released by US-based Maxar Technologies indicate a substantial build-up of Russian troops along Ukraine's borders with western Russia, the Russian-occupied Crimea, and Belarus, a Russian ally.

The US Department of State announced it would halt all visa and consular services in Ukraine starting tomorrow, although it will maintain a small consular presence in Lviv for emergency needs.

title: Shehbaz Sharif becomes new prime minister of Pakistan
content:
**Wednesday, April 13, 2022**

On Monday, the National Assembly of Pakistan elected Shehbaz Sharif, the former chief minister of Punjab province and a member of the Pakistan Muslim League (N), as the country's new prime minister. This followed the ousting of Imran Khan, the previous prime minister since 2018 and leader of the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf party, who lost a no-confidence vote on Sunday. Before the vote, Khan had attempted to dissolve the Assembly to call for early elections, but the Supreme Court of Pakistan ruled this move unconstitutional, thus reinstating the Assembly.

Shehbaz Sharif secured 174 votes in the 342-seat Assembly, while all 155 members of the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf resigned in protest before the voting took place. Khan, who has alleged that a U.S.-led conspiracy was behind his removal, called for nationwide protests, which saw tens of thousands of demonstrators in cities including Lahore and Peshawar.

In his address to the Assembly, Sharif emphasized the need for "hard work, and unity, unity and unity," asserting, "If we have to save the sinking boat, what we all need is unity." He was subsequently sworn into office at Aiwan-e-Sadr, the presidential palace.

Shehbaz Sharif is the younger brother of former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, who is currently undergoing medical treatment abroad after being sentenced to 10 years in prison for corruption in 2018. Shehbaz Sharif remains under investigation for corruption himself and may face charges in the future.

title: Teenager fatally stabbed at Sydney Royal Easter Show in Australia
content:
**Wednesday, April 13, 2022**

A 17-year-old boy has died and a 16-year-old boy is in serious condition in a hospital following a fight at the Royal Easter Show in Sydney, Australia, on Monday around 8 p.m. Sydney time (10:00 UTC). 

According to New South Wales Ambulance Inspector Mark Whittaker, the 17-year-old, who worked at the event, suffered cardiac arrest after being stabbed in the chest in front of his parents. Paramedics performed CPR before transporting him to Westmead Hospital, where he was pronounced dead. The 16-year-old is receiving treatment for stab wounds to his leg.

A 15-year-old boy was arrested at the show for his involvement in the stabbing and taken to Auburn Police Station. He has appeared in juvenile court and was granted bail on charges of affray, carrying a knife in public, and being armed with intent.

Strike force detectives are actively searching for others connected to the stabbing, which they believe was a premeditated confrontation between two groups rather than a random attack.
