In response to the incident, the adult section of the carnival was closed to allow for forensic investigations. Show manager Murray Wilton rejected claims of inadequate security, stating that while it’s impractical to check all attendees' bags, random bag checks were conducted.

Event organizers have announced that full refunds will be provided for those who choose not to attend the show anymore.

Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison expressed his condolences, stating, "All our kids will be going to the Royal Easter Show. My kids will be going to the Royal Easter Show. We want them to be safe. This is a very distressing event. The violence that is there, has no place. It has no place in this country. It has no place at an event where people are coming to enjoy themselves."

Superintendent Danielle Emerton of the New South Wales Police Force reassured the public of the show’s safety and urged anyone with information about the incident to come forward, noting, "We know that there were thousands of people at the show last night and we know that there's a lot of vision that is out there."

title: UK Supreme Court will not hear Julian Assange's appeal against extradition
content:
**Tuesday, March 15, 2022**

The Supreme Court of the United Kingdom announced yesterday that it will not hear Julian Assange's appeal against his extradition to the United States. The court stated that the application "didn’t raise an arguable point of law," thereby upholding a December ruling that deemed Assange eligible for extradition, contingent upon assurances from the US regarding humane treatment.

Assange, an Australian citizen, is the founder of WikiLeaks, which published classified US military documents obtained from whistleblower Chelsea Manning. He faces criminal charges in the US for allegedly assisting Manning in acquiring those documents. Assange's defense argues that he was merely fulfilling his duties as a journalist.

Since 2019, Assange has been incarcerated at Belmarsh Prison in London. Before that, he spent seven years at the Ecuadorian embassy in London to evade extradition to Sweden on sexual assault charges, which have since been dropped.

The decision regarding his extradition now rests with UK Home Secretary Priti Patel, and Assange's legal team has four weeks to file any objections.

title: Court finds UK allowed undervalued Chinese imports into EU
content:
**Friday, March 11, 2022**

On Tuesday, the European Court of Justice (ECJ) determined that the United Kingdom failed to meet its responsibilities as a former European Union member by permitting "undervalued imports of textiles and footwear from China" into EU markets.

The European Commission contended that HM Revenue and Customs did not fulfill its obligations under EU law, resulting in inadequate collection of customs duties and value-added tax payments for imports of Chinese clothing and footwear between 2011 and 2017. An investigation by the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) in 2017 revealed that over half of the imported products were found to be priced below "the lowest acceptable prices".

These lowest acceptable prices serve as a risk assessment tool created by OLAF to identify "imports presenting a significant risk of undervaluation". OLAF alerted member states about the potential for "extreme undervaluation" by shell companies during bilateral discussions with the UK in 2015 and 2016. Nonetheless, the ECJ concluded that British authorities did not employ this metric in their monitoring efforts from 2011 to 2014.

Consequently, the UK failed to conduct "appropriate customs controls," allowing the products to circulate freely within the internal market. For instance, fraud investigators in 2017 discovered that women’s trousers from China were declared at €0.91 per kilogram, which was €0.53 less than the market price for cotton. The Commission estimates this situation cost the EU budget approximately €2.68 billion (around $2.9 billion) from 2011 to 2017, as 80% of customs duties contribute to funding the EU budget.

However, the ECJ rejected the Commission’s request for the UK to repay this sum due to discrepancies in the calculations provided, which were deemed not to meet the "requisite legal standard". The UK continues to fall under ECJ jurisdiction for infractions committed during its EU membership, even after exiting the EU in January 2020. The court mandated that the UK cover four-fifths of the legal costs incurred by Brussels since OLAF first raised concerns in 2017.

While the UK has the option to challenge the fine, it cannot contest the judgment itself. The imposed fine of €2.68 billion is an increase from the original €1.99 billion identified from a sophisticated fraud scheme. Although the current figure pertains to the 2011-2017 period, the investigation initially focused on evidence gathered from 2013 to 2016 at the ports of Felixstowe and Dover in England.

At that time, a spokesperson for then-Prime Minister Theresa May stated that the sum was "not a bill. It's an estimate," and emphasized, "we don't recognize the figures."

The Luxembourg-based court concluded that the British government failed "to apply effective customs control measures or to accurately record the correct amounts of customs duties." It further noted that the "inadequate nature of checks undertaken by the UK customs authorities" allowed fraudulent shell companies to relocate their operations to the UK.

Additionally, the ECJ found that the UK did not provide the Commission with all the necessary information for its own calculations.

The UK continued to resist EU methodologies for assessing undervalued goods, a stance supported by Belgium, Estonia, Greece, Latvia, Portugal, and Slovakia. Among these, Portugal, Slovakia, and the UK, alongside Malta and Spain, were identified as having "major undervaluation hubs" during the first month of OLAF's 2014 Operation Snake.

British ports, especially Dover, emerged as primary entry points for Chinese goods before they cleared European customs and were distributed across the continent. In 2016, Bruno Collin, head of a French anti-fraud operation, expressed frustration to Politico Europe regarding the lack of cooperation from British authorities, stating they provided only "extremely vague answers" to French inquiries, if they responded at all.

When OLAF initially reported on the UK's "continuous negligence" in combating fraud, HM Revenue asserted to Politico Europe that it maintained an "excellent record in tackling fraud and rule-breaking of all kinds." However, Collin remarked: "They don't make an effort."

title: South African floods kill at least 300 people
content:
**Friday, April 15, 2022**

On Wednesday, heavy rains and subsequent flooding in KwaZulu-Natal province, including the major port city of Durban, resulted in over 300 fatalities. The flooding hindered rescue operations by the South African National Defence Force, although some helicopters and personnel were deployed, as confirmed by General Rudzani Maphwanya. Authorities are actively working to restore electricity to the affected areas.

President Cyril Ramaphosa stated, "This disaster is a manifestation of climate change. It underscores the urgency of addressing climate change; it is serious and present. We can no longer delay necessary actions and measures."

The eThekwini Metropolitan Municipality experienced significant damage. Mayor Mxolisi Kaunda reported challenges in accessing power and water facilities. Sipho Hlomuka, part of the Executive Council for Co-operative Governance and Traditional Affairs in KwaZulu-Natal, noted, "The heavy rains have impacted power lines across many municipalities, and technical teams are working tirelessly to restore electricity."

title: Motion on transgender women in sports defeated in Queensland Parliament
content:
**Friday, May 13, 2022**

The Parliament of Queensland, Australia, rejected a motion on Wednesday from Katter's Australian Party (KAP) that claimed allowing transgender women to participate in women's sports would undermine the integrity of female sports. The motion argued that "anyone who supports biological men playing in female sports, regardless of age group, level, or code, is complicit in eroding the integrity of female sport and, consequently, women's rights." It contended that transgender women pose "insurmountable physical advantages," creating an "unfair competitive edge" and safety risks for other athletes in women's sports.

The motion was defeated by a vote of 49 to 33, with support from the KAP, the Liberal National Party (LNP), and Pauline Hanson's One Nation, while the Labor government and the Greens opposed it. KAP leader Robbie Katter addressed Parliament, stating he believed the issue was "important for parents." He expressed concern for his young daughters and said, "Imagining them at 15 or 17 years old, post-puberty, competing against someone who might transition to female, that doesn't sit well with me." Katter emphasized he did not want to deny anyone the chance to compete in sports but noted that there is a "distinct advantage when you cross over." He also referenced the upcoming federal election, indicating the need to take a stance on relevant social issues.

Queensland Sporting Minister Stirling Hinchliffe opposed the motion, labeling it a "blatant dog whistle" and asserting, "This is not a debate about sport or women's rights. It is an attempt to instigate fear and division, unnecessarily dragging an extreme right-wing narrative into this parliament." He criticized making generalizations based solely on gender identity, calling such a move "draconian and bigoted."

Representatives from all parties except the LNP participated in the debate, which lasted around 30 minutes. KAP Hinchinbrook MP Nick Dametto suggested there might be individuals who would exploit gender identity to enter women's sports, saying, "we may see an opportunity for guys who now identify as women to put on a wig and jump into women's sport because maybe they are washed up at the NRL," arguing that allowing "full access" for transgender individuals in female sports was neither fair nor safe. One Nation MP Stephen Andrew supported the motion, claiming that failure to advocate for the rights of all individuals could lead to the eventual disappearance of women's sports.

The two Greens representatives opposed the motion. Amy MacMahon, representing South Brisbane, asserted that "this motion today is not about women; it is about stoking transmisogyny for cheap political gain." She advocated for equal pay for women athletes, increased visibility of women's sports on television, and programs to encourage female participation in sports. Greens leader Michael Berkman condemned the motion as "repugnant" and "unnecessary," noting the lack of opposition voices speaking against it.

title: Ten-year Tennessee study shows preschool associated with poorer student performance
content:
**Friday, February 11, 2022**

A team led by Dale Farran challenged the notion that prekindergarten provides long-term benefits for children in a recently published paper in Developmental Psychology. The research involved 2,990 low-income children from Tennessee, USA, who applied to the state's free public preschools. This study utilized a natural experiment design, as enrollment was determined by lottery rather than merit. Researchers recorded the academic and personal achievements of the students from preschool through sixth grade nearly a decade later.

Findings revealed that, while pre-K graduates initially seemed better prepared for school, their peers who did not attend preschool eventually caught up. By the end of second grade, those who had not participated in preschool were outperforming their counterparts who had. The gap continued to widen: by sixth grade, students who skipped preschool exhibited fewer disciplinary problems, lower absenteeism rates, and were less likely to require special education services. There was no significant difference in dropout rates between the two groups.

In 2015, then-Governor of Tennessee Bill Haslam questioned whether the quality of preschool programs could be a contributing factor. Steven Barnett from Rutgers University's National Institute for Early Education Research concurred, pinpointing several flaws in the state's approach to establishing new preschools, particularly the absence of quality control, which left uncertainty regarding the effectiveness of classroom instruction.

All preschool classes included in the study were taught by licensed teachers in the same facilities as public schools for older children. A similar research effort focused on Boston, Massachusetts, published in 2021, indicated that preschool was associated with improved academic and disciplinary outcomes, which contradicted Farran's findings.

Farran hypothesized that the unexpected results might stem from the level of control and discipline exerted by teachers. Most Tennessee preschool instructors were certified to teach pre-K through fifth or eighth grade, meaning their specialized training for children under five was limited. Additionally, since the preschools were part of larger public school buildings, students often spent considerable time being escorted between classrooms, bathrooms, and cafeterias, where both their movement and noise levels were carefully managed.

As of 2022, Tennessee ranked 38th out of 50 US states in terms of K-12 education quality, according to the World Population Review. President Joe Biden's Build Back Better Plan aims to allocate more funding for early childhood education.

title: UK clarifies foreign, domestic response to cost of living crisis
content:
**Revised Version:**

Monday, March 14, 2022

Wikinews recently obtained clarification from the United Kingdom Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy (BEIS) concerning the government's measures in response to the cost of living crisis stemming from the Russian invasion of Ukraine. 

The UK government foresaw Russian escalation against Ukraine for several months and coordinated responses with NATO and the European Union. Following the invasion in February, many "swift retributive responses" were enacted, including an unprecedented sanctions package that encompasses "financial, trade, aircraft, shipping, and immigration sanctions" aimed at pressuring Russia to halt actions destabilizing Ukraine. A recent commitment by Business Secretary Kwasi Kwarteng on Tuesday to phase out Russian oil and natural gas in the UK by year's end is part of these sanctions.

This announcement coincided with U.S. President Joe Biden's declaration of a ban on imports of Russian oil, coal, and gas. However, a UK government spokesperson emphasized caution, stating: "We cannot have a cliff-edge where oil and gas are abandoned overnight. Turning off the taps would jeopardize energy security, British jobs, and industry, making us even more reliant on foreign imports."

The European Commission is similarly cautious, planning to reduce the EU's Russian import dependence by two-thirds this year and to cease imports "well before 2030." While Russia supplies 40% of the EU's natural gas, much of the UK's energy is generated domestically. The spokesperson highlighted this distinction: "Our single largest source of gas comes from the UK Continental Shelf, with most imports from reliable suppliers such as Norway. There are no gas pipelines directly linking the UK to Russia, and Russian imports accounted for less than 4% of total UK gas supply in 2021."

Ministers continue to engage regularly with energy-intensive industries to manage costs and maintain energy supply. A government FAQ published on February 25 noted that the UK has three liquefied natural gas (LNG) terminals, while Germany has none, urging European countries to reduce reliance on Russian gas through alternative supplies.

A press release issued Tuesday specifically condemned Russian President Vladimir Putin's invasion as "illegal." The spokesperson remarked: "We continue to monitor the impacts of Putin’s unprovoked invasion of Ukraine on the cost of living in the UK and will keep our approach under review." The release asserted that Russian oil "is already being ostracized by the market" and assured that "in a competitive global market for oil and petroleum products, demand can be met by alternative suppliers."

Despite these measures, high inflation, already linked to rising petrol costs, continues to escalate. The Bank of England previously projected inflation would climb to about 7% in spring, up from 5.4% last year, with some economists estimating it could near 8% next month.

Consultancy firm The Centre for Economics and Business Research significantly reduced its 2022 growth expectations from 4.2% to 1.9% on Tuesday. The Institute for Fiscal Studies (IFS) reported that the £9 billion financial support package from Chancellor of the Exchequer Rishi Sunak would offset only about one-fifth of the increase in household energy bills.

A government spokesperson acknowledged concerns regarding the cost of living, stating: "We have introduced a generous support package worth around £21 billion, including a £150 council tax rebate from April and a £200 energy bill discount in October, aimed at quickly reducing energy costs for most households." They added: "This financial year and next, we are providing support to families worth around £20 billion, including adjustments to Universal Credit to ensure that work pays, freezing alcohol and fuel duties to keep costs down, and providing £9.1 billion to assist 27 million households with their energy bills." Notably, all these measures were implemented before the Russian invasion commenced on February 24.

On February 3, it was announced that homeowners in England within Council Tax bands A-D would receive £150 off their council tax payments, alongside a £200 energy bill discount in autumn, which would be automatically repaid over five years—a move criticized by Leader of the Opposition Sir Keir Starmer as a "forced loan."

During Prime Minister's Questions (PMQs) on Wednesday, Starmer criticized Sunak for proposing this loan approach. Prime Minister Boris Johnson defended the £20 billion support package as "unprecedented" and pledged to present an energy independence plan in the coming days.

In his autumn budget statement on October 27, Sunak announced alterations to Universal Credit and the continued freeze on fuel levies. Changes included reducing the Universal Credit taper rate from 63 pence to 55 pence and a sustained freeze on fuel duties that have not been lifted in twelve years, saving motorists an estimated £1900.

The budget statement outlined a "radical simplification" of alcohol duties, reducing taxable bands from fifteen to six while suspending a planned increase, resulting in a £3 billion loss to HM Treasury. This proposal received backing from numerous organizations, including the British Beer and Pub Association.

Despite these measures, criticisms persist regarding their effectiveness. With Sunak's spring statement anticipated on March 23, Conservative MPs have urged the Chancellor to explore additional options. A source indicated that officials in HM Treasury are contemplating alternatives, citing the unprecedented rise in oil prices.

Analysts have projected that household gas and electricity bills could soar to £3000 annually following the invasion. The Office of Gas and Electricity Markets announced it would increase the cap on default energy tariffs by 54% to £1971 starting in April. 

Although oil prices stabilized below USD 120 per barrel on Wednesday, Brent Crude briefly reached a high of $147.50 per barrel, remaining significantly elevated compared to pre-invasion levels. To mitigate the financial strain on British consumers, Sir Keir advocated for increased nuclear energy, renewable resources, and home insulation during PMQs. Johnson defended the government's record on renewables, asserting that the UK is "the Saudi Arabia of wind power." The spokesperson reiterated the need to phase out reliance on Russian oil and gas in Europe, emphasizing a shift towards nuclear and renewable energy.

The spokesperson noted: "Companies and skilled workers across the UK gas sector are striving to maximize production this winter, supported by several new wells and fields commissioned recently." However, the spokesperson did not address Wikinews' inquiry regarding the Abigail oil field development, approved on February 2 by an Israeli firm. Previously, the Oil and Gas Authority director stated that oil and gas will remain integral to Britain's energy framework for decades.

Continuing, the government spokesperson remarked: "The issues we are currently facing are primarily due to high international gas prices, not supply insufficiencies. Additional UK oil and gas licensing is not expected to bring immediate relief."

The Labour Party has called for the implementation of a windfall profits tax on major fossil fuel companies, including BP and Shell, which reported record-breaking profits for 2021 last month—BP’s profits soaring to $12.8 billion from a loss of $5.7 billion in 2020, and Shell’s climbing to $19.3 billion from $4.85 billion in 2020.

Following BP's announcement, Shadow Chancellor Rachel Reeves stated on Twitter, "The chancellor’s energy plans last week left families more worried than ever. It’s time for Labour’s plan for a one-off windfall tax on oil and gas producers to cut bills." However, during PMQs, Johnson cautioned against a windfall tax, describing it as a "sober, responsible approach" and warning that such a tax could prompt oil companies to raise their prices further, complicating efforts to lessen dependence on Russian oil and gas.

The UK government spokesperson reiterated concerns, stating: "A windfall tax could jeopardize £14 billion worth of impending investment opportunities, risking energy supply security and almost 200,000 jobs reliant on the industry. Oil and gas firms in the North Sea already face a tax rate on their profits that is more than double that levied on other businesses, having contributed over £375 billion in production taxes to date."

The government also faces criticism for its plans to retrofit homes lacking proper insulation. Following the cancellation of the green homes grant last March, which only installed 5800 energy efficiency measures, the spokesperson responded: "We are investing nearly £6.6 billion to support the installation of energy efficiency measures in low-performance homes, particularly for low-income homeowners and tenants. The Heat and Buildings Strategy outlines our comprehensive approach to initiating the transition to low-carbon heat and developing the heat pump market, including a new £450 million Boiler Upgrade Scheme, the £950 million Home Upgrade Grant, and the £60 million Heat Pump Ready research program."

title: Finnish President, Prime Minister announce support for joining NATO
content:
**Saturday, May 14, 2022**

Finnish President Sauli Niinistö and Prime Minister Sanna Marin issued a joint statement on Thursday asserting that "Finland must apply for NATO membership without delay," indicating that the country is likely to seek military alliance membership imminently. 

Historically, following the Winter War and Continuation War against the Soviet Union in the 1940s, Finnish leaders prioritized neutrality and avoided joining NATO. However, public sentiment shifted dramatically after Russia's invasion of Ukraine. In a recent joint press conference with Swedish Prime Minister Magdalena Andersson, Marin mentioned that Finland would decide on NATO membership "within weeks." A recent Yle poll showed 76% of Finns support joining the military alliance.

The joint statement from Niinistö and Marin emphasized, "now that the moment of decision-making is near, we state our equal views, also for information to the parliamentary groups and parties. NATO membership would strengthen Finland's security." They expressed hope that "the national steps still needed to make this decision" would be taken "rapidly within the next few days."

In response, the Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs cautioned that "Helsinki must be aware of the responsibility and consequences of such a move," warning of potential "retaliatory steps, both of a military-technical and other nature, to counter threats to its national security."

This announcement came just a day after Finland and Sweden signed a cooperation agreement with the United Kingdom, committing the UK to defend both nations in case of an attack. During a press conference to unveil the deal on Wednesday, Niinistö remarked that Russia was "ready to attack a neighboring country," and if Russia expressed concern over Finland joining NATO, he would respond with, "you caused this; look in the mirror."

The Social Democratic Party of Finland, led by Marin, is expected to announce its position on NATO membership tomorrow. According to Politico, the party is "almost certain to favor membership." If this aligns with their position, Finland could potentially join the alliance as early as Monday. NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg has previously stated the alliance would welcome both Finland and Sweden, anticipating a swift and uncomplicated accession process. Estonian Prime Minister Kaja Kallas reiterated Estonia's "full support" for Finland's NATO entry, advocating for a rapid accession process.

title: Koalas labeled as 'endangered' in eastern states of Australia
content:
**Monday, February 14, 2022**

On Friday, Australia's federal environment minister, Sussan Ley, announced the classification of the koala as an endangered species in Queensland, New South Wales, and the Australian Capital Territory. This decision follows proposals from the World Wildlife Fund Australia (WWF-Australia) and other organizations made in 2020. Previously, the koala was designated as a vulnerable species, and the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) continues to list it as vulnerable in other parts of the world.

Factors contributing to the decline in the koala population include natural disasters, particularly the devastating bushfire season of 2019-2020, which reportedly "killed, injured, or affected" around 60,000 koalas, according to WWF-Australia. Additionally, ongoing challenges such as drought, urbanization, and habitat destruction have exacerbated the population decline. In response, the government has announced initiatives aimed at preventing the koala's extinction.

A report released in April 2020 highlighted a 50% decline in koala populations in Queensland and a 62% drop in New South Wales since 2001. This prompted WWF-Australia, the International Fund for Animal Welfare (IFAW), and Humane Society International (HSI) to recommend that the IUCN revise the species' status, which had remained 'vulnerable' for a decade. A New South Wales inquiry in June 2020 warned that without effective intervention, koalas could face extinction by 2050.

In her announcement, Ley stated that these alarming trends "have led to the advice" regarding the species’ status change. She emphasized the importance of this decision as a potential turning point for koala conservation, asserting that "there is still time to save this globally iconic species." Ley stressed the need for stronger laws and incentives for landholders to protect koala habitats, noting that AUD 74 million (USD 52.9 million) has been allocated to support these initiatives.

However, some conservation groups have voiced their concerns. Deborah Tabart, president of the Australian Koala Foundation, asserted that the species is also endangered in Victoria and South Australia, criticizing the federal government for permitting habitat loss. HSI campaign director Alexia Wellbelove urged the government to address broader environmental issues, advocating for a review by Graeme Samuel, the former head of the competition watchdog, who previously concluded that the government had failed to take adequate conservation measures and called for a reevaluation of environmental standards.

title: Japan hit by earthquake off coast of Fukushima
content:
**Thursday, March 17, 2022**

At 23:36 JST (14:36 UTC) on Wednesday, a 7.3 magnitude earthquake struck off the coast of Fukushima Prefecture, Japan. According to Prime Minister Fumio Kishida, a Shinkansen train was derailed, but there were no reported injuries from that incident. However, some individuals sustained injuries and were taken to hospitals in Sōma for treatment, with local media reporting one man had died.

Temporary power outages affected approximately 700,000 people as far away as Tokyo, but the Tokyo Electric Power Company quickly restored electricity. 

The Japan Meteorological Agency reported a small tsunami at the coast of Miyagi Prefecture about an hour after the earthquake and issued a tsunami advisory, warning of water levels rising up to 1 meter (3.3 feet) above normal tidal levels. Residents were advised to avoid the coast until the advisory was lifted.

The earthquake's epicenter was located near that of the much more powerful 2011 Tōhoku earthquake, which caused a significant tsunami and a nuclear disaster at the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant. Kishida assured the public that "no abnormalities" were detected at any nuclear facilities following this earthquake.

title: Russia expelled from Council of Europe
content:
**Thursday, March 17, 2022**

The Council of Europe voted yesterday to expel Russia after 26 years of membership, following its suspension on February 25 due to the Russian invasion of Ukraine that began the previous day. 

Russia had already announced its intention to withdraw from the Council on Tuesday. The Council of Europe is an international organization dedicated to promoting human rights and democracy.

In a joint statement from the 46 remaining Council members, the organization expressed, "We have repeatedly condemned the Russian Federation’s aggression against Ukraine." The statement described the invasion as "unjustified and unprovoked aggression," emphasizing that "through their actions in Ukraine, the Russian authorities deprive the Russian people of the benefits of the most advanced human rights protection system in the world."

Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov referred to the Council as "a tool for anti-Russian policy." Meanwhile, Ukraine's Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba stated that there is "no place for Russia in European bodies as it wages a barbaric war of aggression against Ukraine and commits multiple war crimes."

title: GSK rejects three Unilever bids to buy consumer healthcare arm, says unit was "fundamentally undervalued"
content:
**January 16, 2022**

GlaxoSmithKline (GSK), a UK-based pharmaceutical giant, confirmed on January 15 that it has rejected three unsolicited, conditional, and non-binding proposals from Unilever to acquire its Consumer Healthcare division. This includes a bid valued at GBP 50 billion made on December 20, which GSK believes fundamentally undervalues the business and its potential.

The Sunday Times first reported Unilever's attempt to buy GSK Consumer Healthcare for GBP 50 billion, comprising GBP 41.7 billion in cash and GBP 8.3 billion in Unilever shares. Both companies have since confirmed the report. If the acquisition had succeeded, it would have represented the largest deal since the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic and one of the biggest transactions involving companies listed on the London Stock Exchange.

A successful deal would likely involve integrating GSK’s division into Unilever's beauty and personal care business, which has faced profit margin challenges due to COVID-19 lockdowns and rising costs for plastics and petrochemicals.

Unilever's website mentioned that it had approached GSK and Pfizer regarding a potential acquisition, stating that GSK Consumer Healthcare “would be a strong strategic fit.” However, GSK indicated that the proposals were carefully evaluated by its board but were unanimously rejected, concluding they were "not in the best interests of GSK shareholders" and did "not reflect the intrinsic value of the business and its potential."

The Sunday Times noted that the latest proposal lacked an acquisition premium or acknowledgment of corporate synergies. GSK and Pfizer's joint venture was expected to generate GBP 500 million in cost savings by this year, with substantial cost synergies anticipated. BBC business editor Simon Jack highlighted that a typical takeover premium could be around 30%, although this might be offset by GSK's projected GBP 10 billion in debt, part of a total net debt of GBP 22 billion reported for Q3 2021.

The GSK board assessed the proposals in light of a planned demerger of GSK Consumer Health into a separate PLC later this year. Jack noted that GSK maintained an "open mind to a trade sale to another party if the price was right." However, Unilever's proposal did not consider the standard takeover premium, the potential value of cost savings, or the board's confidence that Consumer Health could achieve "superior organic sales growth" of 4% to 6% in the medium term. Analysts from Goldman Sachs and Barclays valued GSK Consumer Healthcare at around GBP 50 billion, while Jeffries Group set a lower estimate of GBP 45 billion.

Currently, there are no ongoing talks between Unilever and either Pfizer or GSK, with Unilever stating, "There can be no certainty that any agreement will be reached." Under CEO Alan Jope, Unilever has focused its investments and marketing on brands that convey a strong environmental or social purpose, while strategically streamlining its portfolio in sectors like beauty products and tea. Jope had previously expressed Unilever's intent to pursue smaller acquisitions in areas such as luxury beauty and wellness.

Russ Mould, investment director at AJ Bell, remarked to the BBC that this would be a "high risk deal," especially considering investor caution regarding GSK's performance amid rising inflation, which he believes favors "consumer goods with loyal customers." Despite Unilever's strong cash flow, the company has recently missed targets for sales and profit margins, exerting additional pressure on the CEO.

Additionally, GSK CEO Emma Walmsley is facing increased scrutiny from activist shareholders Elliott Management Corporation and Bluebell Capital Partners due to the unit's struggles in developing a COVID-19 vaccine and her perceived lack of scientific expertise. GSK is engaged in ongoing vaccine development in collaboration with French biopharmaceutical firm Sanofi and announced preliminary results from Phase 3 trials last month.

In 2018, Unilever acquired several consumer nutritional products from GSK, including its flagship product Horlicks, and merged its Indian subsidiary, Hindustan Unilever, with GSK Consumer Healthcare India.

title: Bans off Our Bodies protests occur across United States after leaked Supreme Court draft
content:
**Revised Version:**

On Saturday, May 14, 2022, thousands participated in the "Bans Off Our Bodies" protests, which organizers claimed were held in over 380 cities and towns across the United States. Demonstrators called for the government to uphold the legality and accessibility of abortion services. Earlier this month, Politico released a leaked draft of a US Supreme Court decision indicating that a majority of justices were prepared to overturn the landmark 1973 Roe v. Wade ruling that legalized abortion nationwide. Protests occurred in major cities, including Atlanta, Chicago, and New York, with approximately 20,000 participants in Washington D.C. alone.

"It's the most critical issue right now because if the leaked opinion takes effect, it could impact various rights—not just reproductive choice but also healthcare rights," said Ann Hoffman, a 79-year-old protester in Washington D.C., who has been advocating for women's rights since the 1970s.

A small group of anti-abortion counter-protesters also gathered in Washington D.C. on the same day. One counter-protester, 24-year-old Anna Lulis from Virginia, held a sign that read, "Women's rights begin in the womb." Police ensured the two groups remained separate, though some confrontations occurred.

If Roe v. Wade were to be overturned, the legality of abortion would revert to individual states. The Guttmacher Institute estimates that 26 of the 50 states are "certain or likely" to impose abortion bans. Many states have already enacted "trigger laws" that would automatically ban abortion if Roe v. Wade is overturned.

The leaked draft pertains to the case of Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization, which was presented to the Court last December. Mississippi had implemented a law prohibiting nearly all abortions after 15 weeks, based on the assertion that a 15-week-old fetus could potentially survive outside the womb with medical assistance. Traditionally, it is understood that a fetus cannot survive outside the uterus until 24 weeks. Through state representative Thomas Dobbs, Mississippi requested that the Supreme Court overturn its 1973 ruling affirming women's constitutional right to abortion, while Jackson Women's Health Organization, the last remaining abortion clinic in the state, contends there is no basis for such a reversal.

Earlier this week, US Senate members attempted to pass federal legislation that would ensure the legality of abortion nationwide, thereby overriding state laws, but fell short of the required votes for approval.

Despite Roe v. Wade, many states have enacted laws restricting abortion access or complicating the process, for instance, by instituting mandatory waiting periods that necessitate patients taking additional time off work. Recently, Texas passed legislation limiting abortions to the first six weeks after the last menstrual period, a timeframe when many women may be unaware of their pregnancy.

President Joe Biden has encouraged Americans to support pro-abortion-rights candidates in the upcoming 2022 midterm elections.

title: UAE President Sheikh Khalifa dies at 73
content:
Tuesday, May 17, 2022 

Sheikh Khalifa bin Zayed Al Nahyan, president of the United Arab Emirates and ruler of Abu Dhabi, passed away on Friday at the age of 73 after struggling with health issues following a heart stroke in 2014. 

He was laid to rest at the Al Bateen cemetery following nationwide prayers and a military honor guard. The Emirati Ministry of Presidential Affairs announced a three-day work suspension in both public and private institutions, as well as a 40-day period of national mourning during which flags will fly at half-mast. 

Condolences have poured in from prominent dignitaries, including U.S. President Joe Biden, Russian President Vladimir Putin, Queen Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom, Israeli Prime Minister Naftali Bennett, and French President Emmanuel Macron. 

Sheikh Mohamed bin Zayed, known as 'MBZ', has succeeded Sheikh Khalifa as the ruler of Abu Dhabi and has been unanimously elected as the new President of the United Arab Emirates by the Federal Supreme Council.

title: UK defers junk food deals, advertisement restrictions
content:
**Tuesday, May 17, 2022**

The United Kingdom's Department of Health and Social Care announced on Friday that the implementation of restrictions on multibuy promotional deals and online and TV advertising for junk food will be postponed for one year. 

This delay impacts the planned ban on promotions encouraging multiple purchases of foods high in fat, salt, or sugar, such as buy one, get one free offers and complimentary soft drink refills. Additionally, the restrictions on paid TV advertisements before 9 p.m. and online advertising will also be deferred. 

According to a Department press release, the postponement is attributed to the "unprecedented global economic situation" and aims to provide businesses "more time to prepare for the restrictions on advertising" while allowing the government to "review and monitor the impact" of the multibuy ban. The statement noted, "Economies around the world have faced higher-than-expected global energy and goods prices, leading to increased costs across supply chains that affect both businesses and consumers."

The ban on multibuy deals will now take effect in October 2023, while the advertising restrictions are postponed until January 2024. However, placement restrictions for such products in stores, at checkouts, and on supermarket websites and apps will still be enforced starting in October 2022 as originally planned. 

Chef and campaigner Jamie Oliver criticized the decision as "a wasted opportunity" that could undermine the obesity strategy, calling for "real leadership" from Prime Minister Boris Johnson to ensure a healthier future for young people. He was supported by Barbara Crowther of the Children's Food Campaign and Graham MacGregor, a cardiologist and campaigner at Queen Mary University of London.

While Public Health Minister Maggie Throup emphasized the government's commitment to helping individuals lead healthier lives, Labour's Andrew Gwynne described the decision as a reversal.

The press release reiterated the government's priority to address obesity, which it claims will help alleviate the strain on the NHS as it recuperates from COVID-19 backlogs. Media, Data and Digital Minister Julia Lopez highlighted an investment of £550 million to improve access to sport and physical activity nationwide, demonstrating the commitment to tackling childhood obesity.

Gwynne argued that Johnson's desire to maintain his position is prioritizing Conservative MPs' ideologies over children's health, stating, "Instead of cutting childhood obesity, preventing ill-health and easing pressure on the NHS, this chaotic government is performing another U-turn." The Independent reported that some backbench Conservative MPs criticized the delay, viewing it as a reinforcement of a "nanny state."

Reports suggest that Johnson made the decision following a ministerial meeting on the cost of living last Wednesday, where ministers outlined the potential financial impact of the bans on food and advertising agencies. Additionally, The Guardian and The Independent noted speculation that the government might ultimately scrap the restrictions altogether. MacGregor lamented that Johnson had the opportunity to leave a significant legacy in combating obesity but instead capitulated to his MPs and an aggressive food industry, which had begun to comply with the proposals.

When the restrictions were initially announced in November 2020, 800 food and drink manufacturers, including Britvic and Kellogg's, criticized the ban as "disproportionate," claiming that the evidence supporting these proposals was insufficient. Last month, Kellogg's even took legal action against the government regarding product placement restrictions.

The Food and Drink Federation supported the delay, citing "high inflation" as a logical reason, whereas the Children's Food Campaign contended that multibuy deals do not benefit consumers financially but rather encourage greater junk food purchases. Recent figures revealed that two in five Britons are purchasing less food as the Bank of England warns that inflation could exceed 10% this year.

The press release also promised a public consultation on TV and paid online advertisements in the coming weeks. Broadcasters could stand to lose over £200 million in annual revenue if the ban on junk food advertising post-watershed is enacted.

In light of these developments, the government promoted its recently passed calorie labeling laws and efforts to alleviate the cost of living. The Department also announced plans to publish a Health Disparities white paper and launch a Better Health: Rewards scheme aimed at addressing obesity.

title: Hungary extends fuel price cap
content:
**Wednesday, February 16, 2022**

On Saturday, Prime Minister Viktor Orbán announced a three-month extension of Hungary's price cap on standard motor fuels, originally implemented on November 15 and set to expire on Sunday. The government aims to curb inflation and support the economy with this initiative, although it does not provide compensation to petrol stations for their losses. A general election is scheduled for April 3, where all opposition parties in Parliament, except one, have united to challenge the ruling Fidesz-KDNP alliance, which has been in power for twelve years.

Orbán made the announcement during his annual speech, stating, "The 'price-stop' has proven effective, so we will extend it for an additional three months." The official gazette, Magyar Közlöny, published the corresponding government resolution No. 39/2022 the following day. A week earlier, Deputy Finance Minister András Tállai informed the news agency MTI that tax authority inspections of over 2,000 fuel stations found no recurring violations of the price cap, although 12 stations were fined a total of HUF 3.2 million (USD 10,140). "The stations are adhering to the established rules, which is evident in the absence of repeated violations over the past three months," Tállai added.

Orbán noted, "We have the fifth lowest fuel price in the European Union. Currently, we pay 480 forints per liter, but without the 'price-stop,' we would be paying well over 500 forints." According to price-aggregator site holtankoljak.hu, uncapped prices have reached HUF 512 for gasoline and HUF 530 for diesel, with wholesale prices surpassing consumer prices since February 4. Data from the aggregator indicated that three stations permanently closed in the first week of February due to the price cap. By law, the government can appoint new operators for these closed stations.

On November 10, the government introduced the HUF 480 (USD 1.52) price cap, with further details communicated to the press the following day. The corresponding act, government resolution No. 624/2021, was published in the official gazette on the day of the announcement, while follow-up resolution No. 626/2021, published on November 13, outlined the implementation process. The cap applies to unleaded 95 and standard diesel fuels, excluding liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) and premium fuels. However, stations that do not sell standard fuels must offer premium fuels at the capped price.

As a result, retail petrol stations incur losses as they cannot negotiate wholesale prices. During a press briefing on November 11, Minister in the Prime Minister's Office Gergely Gulyás stated that there are no plans to compensate these losses, adding that "vendors cannot be forced to trade." The following day, Ottó Grád, secretary general of the Hungarian Petroleum Association, indicated that owners of small, independent stations might consider closing. Contrary to Gulyás' comments, the detailed resolution stipulates that petrol stations cannot close temporarily or reduce their operating hours.

The government has also indicated that it does not plan to lower tax rates on fuel. Last week, the European Commission’s oil bulletin revealed that taxes account for 47% of the consumer price for unleaded 95 and 45% for standard diesel in Hungary. Cumulative data from the Hungarian Petroleum Association for 2021 shows that unleaded 95 represents 79% of all gasoline sales, while standard diesel constitutes 88% of diesel sales in the country. Between 2020 and 2021, consumer prices surged for unleaded 95 from HUF 332 to 506 and for standard diesel from HUF 341 to 517, according to price-comparison site holtankoljak.hu. Additionally, 444.hu reported that deteriorating HUF-USD exchange rates contributed to rising prices even in July, despite declining crude oil prices.

The Hungarian Central Statistical Office reported that inflation reached 7.9% in January. In his speech announcing the extension, Prime Minister Orbán claimed the fuel price cap has reduced inflation by 0.5%.

title: Signs of de-escalation as Russia claims to pull back some troops
content:
**Wednesday, February 16, 2022** 

On Tuesday, German Chancellor Olaf Scholz met with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Moscow to discuss the ongoing crisis along the Russian-Ukrainian border. Prior to this meeting, Scholz visited Kiev on Monday, where he met with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky to express support for Ukraine in the face of Russian aggression.

During a joint press conference following the meeting, Scholz emphasized that it is "our absolute duty as heads of government that Europe does not see an escalation into war." In response to inquiries about military deployments and the threat of conflict, Putin stated that Russia does "not want war in Europe." He added that Russia is "ready to work further together" and is willing to "go down the negotiations track."

However, Putin also reiterated Russia's positions, referring to them as valid and labeling the situation in Ukraine’s Donbas region as a form of "genocide." On the same day, the Russian Defence Ministry announced the beginning of troop withdrawals, characterizing the movements as a "military drill."

Chancellor Scholz regarded the withdrawal of some troops as a positive development. Conversely, Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba stated that Ukraine would not accept any Russian claims until they are verified, asserting, "if we see a withdrawal, we will believe in a de-escalation." NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg welcomed Russia's indication of a willingness to seek a diplomatic solution but noted that there had been "no sign of de-escalation on the ground" as of yet.

title: Bandit ringleader arrested in Nigeria
content:
**Saturday, March 19, 2022**

On Friday, police in Nigeria apprehended Ahmed Yunusa, also known as "Yellow Ashana," an alleged highwayman in Kaduna State. Several of Yunusa's associates were arrested as well, including Nvou Michael, who is reportedly a gunrunner for the gang. The arrests were executed by the FIB-STS divisions of the Nigeria Police Force.

The gang is accused of terrorizing communities along the highway connecting Abuja and Kaduna and has been linked to bank robberies in Ondo State. Authorities state that Yunusa has confessed to involvement in kidnappings and killings.

Michael was captured at a different location, where she was found with 15 rifles and 400 rounds of ammunition.

title: Peru's top court restores pardon for ex-President Fujimori
content:
**Saturday, March 19, 2022**

On Thursday, Peru's Constitutional Court reinstated a humanitarian pardon for former President Alberto Fujimori, who was convicted on charges of murder and corruption. 

Fujimori, who is now 83 years old, was originally set to be released in 2032 after serving a 25-year sentence. He was granted a pardon in 2017 by then-President Pedro Pablo Kuczynski due to health issues, including a heart condition. However, this pardon was revoked in 2018, leading to his return to prison. The court's recent decision reinstating the pardon is expected to result in his release by Monday or Tuesday, according to his lawyer, Cesar Nakazaki, pending some procedural requirements.

Supporters of Fujimori gathered outside the prison, while protests erupted in Lima against the court's ruling. Current President Pedro Castillo expressed his concerns on Twitter, calling on international justice bodies associated with Peru to ensure the fair administration of justice for its citizens.

Fujimori served as president from 1990 to 2000 and spent five years in exile in Japan before attempting to return to Peru for a new presidential campaign, where he was arrested in Chile and subsequently extradited.

title: Scientists announce decoy-proof Ebola antibodies
content:
**Saturday, March 19, 2022**

A groundbreaking study published on Thursday in *Cell* unveils a new antibody treatment for the lethal diseases caused by the Ebola virus and its relatives. Researchers from the La Jolla Institute for Immunology (LJI) and the National Institute for Allergy and Infectious Diseases have identified two antibodies, 1C3 and 1C11, that effectively target both Zaire ebolavirus and Sudan ebolavirus.

Currently, there are no available vaccines or antibody treatments specifically for ebolaviruses other than Zaire ebolavirus. LJI President and CEO Erica Ollmann Saphire emphasized the significance of discovering antibodies with such broad efficacy, stating, "Finding antibodies with this breadth is important because we don't know which virus in the genus of ebolaviruses is going to break out next."

Among the six ebolaviruses known to science, Zaire and Sudan are the deadliest, with the 2010 outbreak of the Zaire virus resulting in over 11,000 fatalities. A key advancement reported in this study is the use of cryogenic electron microscopy to visualize how and where the antibodies interact with the viruses.

The research revealed that antibody 1C3 binds to the viral glycoprotein not in the usual lock-and-key manner, but rather sideways, simultaneously blocking three binding sites. Antibodies neutralize pathogens by attaching to their antigens. Meanwhile, 1C11 disrupts the virus's ability to enter human cells. Since Zaire and Sudan ebolaviruses employ remarkably similar mechanisms, 1C11 proves effective against both.

The primary advantage of these new antibodies lies in their resistance to cross-reactivity. When viruses like Zaire and Sudan ebolaviruses invade the body, they often release excess glycoprotein that can mislead antibodies, causing up to 90 percent to bind to this decoy rather than the actual virus. In contrast, 1C3 and 1C11 specifically target the genuine pathogen.

This specificity allows treatments utilizing 1C3 and 1C11 to be effective even at lower doses compared to other therapies. Preliminary tests in non-human primates have shown that even minimal doses were 100 percent effective, suggesting that human treatments may be more economically viable than previously thought.

LJI scientists highlight two significant benefits of using these antibodies. First, they enable the treatment of patients with unidentified ebolavirus species using an effective antibody cocktail targeting multiple viruses—a crucial factor when time is critical. Second, these antibodies could remain effective in patients at later stages of the disease.

The experiments were conducted using samples donated to Emory University by two Ebola survivors.

title: ICJ orders Russia to stop Ukrainian invasion 'immediately'
content:
**Date: Friday, March 18, 2022**

On Wednesday, the International Court of Justice (ICJ) ordered Russia to "immediately suspend military operations" in Ukraine, with a decisive vote of 13–2. The ruling, which opposed the Russian invasion, was rejected by Russia and China.

Ukraine initiated the case on February 26, just two days after the onset of the invasion. Russia characterized its actions as a "special military operation" aimed at safeguarding Russian-speaking communities in Eastern Ukraine from alleged genocide, a claim that Ukraine contests as baseless. During the proceedings, Russia argued it was acting in self-defense.

Ukrainian representative to the ICJ, Anton Korynevych, asserted, "Russia must be stopped." Ukraine argued that the United Nations Genocide Convention does not allow for invasion as a form of defense against genocide and denied any intentions or actions that could be construed as such.

The court ultimately ruled in favor of Ukraine, stating, "The civilian population affected by the present conflict is extremely vulnerable. The 'special military operation' conducted by the Russian Federation has led to numerous civilian casualties and injuries."

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky celebrated the decision on Twitter, declaring, "Ukraine gained a complete victory in its case." He also emphasized, "Ignoring the order will isolate Russia even further."

Previously, Russia had boycotted the ICJ hearing, filing a response on March 7 that claimed the court lacks jurisdiction in this matter. While the ICJ's ruling favored Ukraine, the court has no means to enforce its decisions.

Despite the ruling, Russian military actions continue to target Ukrainian cities, causing significant damage to civilian infrastructure. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees reported that approximately 3 million Ukrainians have fled to neighboring countries since the invasion began.

title: Clash between Palestinians and Israeli forces leaves at least 155 injured
content:
**Sunday, April 17, 2022**

On Friday, clashes erupted between Palestinians and Israeli police at the Al-Aqsa Mosque compound, where thousands had gathered to observe the Islamic holy month of Ramadan. The Palestine Red Crescent Society reported treating 152 individuals who were injured during the confrontations. The mosque, situated in the Old City of Jerusalem, holds significance for both Muslims and Jews.

According to a statement from Israeli police, hundreds of Palestinians congregated within the mosque compound, launching firecrackers and stones towards the adjacent Western Wall, a sacred site for Jews. In response, police deployed tear gas and stun grenades to disperse the crowd and maintain safety for other worshippers. At least three police officers sustained injuries during the incident.

The Hashemite royal family of Jordan, which oversees the mosque's custodianship, voiced concerns over the violence, labeling it "a dangerous and condemnable escalation that threatens to inflame the situation." Conversely, Israel's public security minister, Omer Bar-Lev, dismissed these allegations, asserting that Israel had "no interest" in escalating violence at the holy site.

In recent weeks, a series of Palestinian attacks has resulted in the deaths of 14 people in Israel. The overlap of the Islamic holy month of Ramadan and the Jewish Passover this year may have contributed to heightened tensions between the two communities, according to sources.

title: V/Line regional trains in Victoria, Australia disrupted after communications fault
content:
**Thursday, May 19, 2022**

Regional railway services operated by Australian train operator V/Line were suspended Wednesday morning due to what was described as a "communications outage." Services to various Victorian destinations, including Ballarat, Bendigo, Geelong, Gippsland, and Seymour, were impacted. A V/Line spokesperson indicated that the outage disrupted communication between the control center and trains, necessitating the suspension of services.

Although disruptions persisted throughout Wednesday, trains resumed normal speeds after a backup system was implemented. Passengers were warned to expect delays of up to an hour as routes came back online. V/Line is currently investigating the issue and stated, "We realize how frustrating this is, and we're working as hard as we can to rectify the situation as quickly as possible."

title: Scientists use DNA analysis to track elephant poaching networks
content:
**Friday, February 18, 2022**

A study published on Monday in Nature Human Behaviour by a team primarily from the University of Washington Center for Forensic Science has revealed a novel application of DNA analysis techniques, originally developed for human dental studies, to trace ivory poached from African elephants. In collaboration with the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, the researchers successfully identified criminal networks responsible for the poaching of these endangered animals and the smuggling of their valuable tusks across international borders.

The scientists analyzed DNA samples from 4,320 tusks confiscated from both African bush (Loxodonta africana) and African forest (Loxodonta cyclotis) elephants over 49 separate ivory smuggling incidents in twelve countries from 2002 to 2019. Their findings indicated that tusks from closely related elephants, or even from the same individual, were frequently found in different shipments passing through the same ports. The study also highlighted how these criminal networks adjusted their operations between various port cities, suggesting that poachers killed elephants and separated the tusks at intervals along the smuggling routes.

The research team, which has been investigating DNA analysis of poached tusks for several years, previously discovered in 2018 that two tusks from distinct shipments originated from the same animal, indicating that both shipments came from the same kill and were trafficked by the same criminal network. This study marks the first documented identification of tusks linked to elephants within the same familial group.

Lead author Dr. Samuel Wasser emphasized the significance of these findings: "Identifying close relatives suggests that poachers are likely returning to the same populations repeatedly—year after year—resulting in tusks being acquired and smuggled out of Africa by the same criminal networks." He further noted that this strategy complicates law enforcement efforts to track and seize ivory shipments, given the tremendous pressure to rapidly process large volumes of goods at ports.

Wasser expressed hope that similar studies would furnish law enforcement with a broader array of evidence to effectively prosecute poachers and their collaborators by establishing verifiable connections among different ivory caches. The authors concluded that their research could assist authorities in understanding how poachers collaborate.

Humans have utilized ivory from elephant tusks for artistic, decorative, and practical purposes since prehistoric times. Despite numerous countries outlawing ivory sales, poaching continues to claim the lives of tens of thousands of elephants each year.

The study's authors include researchers from the University of Washington, the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, the Kenyan organization SeeJ-Africa, the Kenya Wildlife Service, and Singapore's National Parks Board.

title: Japanese PM Kishida visits India, discusses business partnership
content:
**Sunday, March 20, 2022**

On Saturday, Prime Minister of Japan Fumio Kishida met with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi during his two-day official visit for the 14th India-Japan Annual Summit.

The discussions focused on enhancing the strategic business partnership and fostering international cooperation between the two nations. This marked Kishida's first visit to India as Prime Minister since he assumed office in October of the previous year.

Kishida announced a commitment of JPY 5 trillion in public and private investment and financing for India over the next five years. The leaders also explored advancements in the information and technology sector, celebrating the launch of the India-Japan Digital Partnership, and expressed optimism regarding the Mumbai–Ahmedabad High-Speed Rail project.

Both leaders reaffirmed their commitment to promoting peace and prosperity in the Indo-Pacific region. They called for an immediate halt to violence in Myanmar and condemned North Korea's attempts to test nuclear-capable ballistic missiles.

Furthermore, they urged an immediate cessation of hostilities in the context of the Russian invasion of Ukraine and emphasized the importance of safeguarding Ukraine's sovereignty. Japan and India pledged to facilitate humanitarian aid to Ukraine. Both nations are members of the Quadrilateral Security Dialogue (QUAD), which includes Australia and the United States; notably, India has not yet condemned the invasion due to its strong ties with Russia.

Additionally, Kishida and Modi expressed support for establishing an agreement for the reciprocal provision of supplies and services between their armed forces, aimed at facilitating multilateral military exercises. Kishida also extended an invitation to Modi for the upcoming QUAD summit in Japan.

Kishida departed India today and is set to meet with Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen.

title: American Museum of Natural History removes statue of Theodore Roosevelt
content:
**Friday, January 21, 2022**

The American Museum of Natural History in New York City removed the "Equestrian Statue of Theodore Roosevelt" on Thursday, a decision that followed over a year of controversy. The statue, which has depicted Roosevelt riding a horse flanked by a Native American and an African American on foot, had stood at the museum's entrance since 1940 as a tribute to the 26th President of the United States, recognized by the museum as "a devoted naturalist and author of works on natural history."

The museum requested the statue's removal in June 2020 amid global protests triggered by the killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis. In their statement, the museum noted that "the statue itself communicates a racial hierarchy that the Museum and members of the public have long found disturbing."

Support for the removal came from former New York Mayor Bill de Blasio, Roosevelt's great-grandson Theodore Roosevelt IV, and the New York City Public Design Commission (NYCPDC), which resolved to remove and temporarily store the statue.

The New York Young Republican Club has defended the statue, with club leader Gavin Wax stating in 2020, "This was about a cultural revolution engulfing our nation. We need to stand up; we have history on our side." In November, it was announced that the statue would be relocated to the Theodore Roosevelt Presidential Library in Medora, North Dakota.

title: Australian authorities probe rapid antigen test price gouging
content:
**Friday, January 21, 2022**

The Australian Federal Police (AFP) announced today the launch of an investigation into allegations of price gouging related to COVID-19 rapid antigen tests (RATs), following referrals from the Australian Competition & Consumer Commission (ACCC). The AFP cautioned that price gouging could result in a penalty of up to five years in prison and a fine of AUD 66,000.

According to Australian law, price gouging occurs when an individual or business purchases a rapid antigen test kit from a retailer and then sells it for more than 20% above the purchase price. This regulation does not apply to businesses that acquire kits from wholesalers. The AFP has the authority to seize test kits and transfer them to the national medical stockpile if they suspect price gouging is taking place.

In a statement, the AFP reported that two investigations have been initiated in New South Wales and Queensland, with more anticipated in the future. These investigations will be managed by Taskforce LOTUS, established by the AFP in 2021 to address risks associated with the COVID-19 vaccine rollout. The taskforce will refer allegations of price gouging to specialized strike teams deployed across Australia.

AFP Assistant Commissioner Nigel Ryan emphasized that the AFP will maintain a zero-tolerance policy for profiteering from rapid antigen tests. "The AFP will utilize its full authority to combat RAT price gouging. Not only is this practice unethical, but it is also illegal, and the AFP is committed to using its extensive resources to safeguard the public from such unlawful exploitation,” Assistant Commissioner Ryan asserted.

"Commonwealth and state agencies are collaborating on this matter, and under Taskforce LOTUS, the AFP has no qualms about enforcing the law to ensure the safety of Australians. Those who violate the law could face up to five years in prison or a AUD 66,000 fine. My message is unequivocal: do not gamble with your freedom or risk heavy fines for a few extra dollars."

On Monday, the ACCC revealed it has received 1,800 reports from consumers since December 25, highlighting instances where tests were priced as high as AUD 500 for two on online marketplaces and AUD 70 each at convenience stores. "At the most extreme end, we have documented reports or media coverage of tests priced at up to AUD 500 for a pair of tests through online platforms and over AUD 70 per test at convenience stores, service stations, and independent supermarkets, which is absolutely outrageous," stated ACCC Chair Rod Sims. 

"There are several businesses that have consistently come to our attention due to information provided by the public. We are urging these businesses to urgently justify the prices they are charging."

title: North Korea offers amnesty to criminals, marking important holidays
content:
**Friday, January 21, 2022**

On January 20, state-operated media outlet Voice of Korea reported that the North Korean government has issued a decree granting amnesty to individuals convicted of "crimes against the country and the people." This decree was established to celebrate the upcoming birth anniversaries of former leaders Kim Il-sung and Kim Jong-il.

According to Voice of Korea, the decree, issued by the Standing Committee of the Supreme People's Assembly under decree No. 820, will take effect on January 30. The Supreme People's Assembly is identified as "the highest organ of State power" in North Korea, as noted in the country's constitution.

The birth anniversary of founding leader Kim Il-sung, known as the "Day of the Sun," is celebrated annually on April 15, while the birth anniversary of second leader Kim Jong-il, referred to as the "Day of the Shining Star," is observed on February 16. Both dates are significant holidays in North Korea, marked by elaborate celebrations in previous years.

An article from The Korea Herald suggests that this amnesty is intended "to promote social unity amid economic hardships" and "to boost loyalty for the leader [Kim Jong-un]," linking the ongoing economic challenges faced by the North to the COVID-19 border closures.

title: China Eastern jet with 132 onboard crashes in Guangxi
content:
**Monday, March 21, 2022**

China Eastern Airlines Flight 5735 tragically crashed in the mountains of Guangxi near Wuzhou. The Civil Aviation Administration of China has confirmed that there were 123 passengers and 9 crew members on board. Personnel have been dispatched to the crash site, but no survivors have been reported, and the cause of the accident remains unknown.

Amateur video footage, aired by state media, captured the aircraft in a rapid nosedive before the impact. Local media indicated that the crash ignited a forest fire in the vicinity, which has since been extinguished. The flight had departed from Kunming at 13:11 CST (05:11 UTC) and was en route to Guangzhou. Given the severity of the crash, it is feared that there are no survivors.

The aircraft involved was a 6-year-old Boeing 737-800, registered as B-1791. According to data from ground-based ADS-B stations provided by Flightradar24, the plane descended from an altitude of 29,100 feet (8,870 meters) to 3,225 feet (983 meters) in just three minutes.

China Eastern Airlines has not yet issued a statement concerning the crash but has reportedly greyed out its website as a symbol of mourning. China is known for its strong aviation safety record, largely due to stringent aviation regulations. The last fatal air disaster in China occurred in 2010 when an Embraer E190 operated by Henan Airlines crashed while approaching in low visibility conditions.

title: Indian steel giant stops business with Russia
content:
On Wednesday, Tata Steel, the Indian steel giant, announced that it is severing all business ties with Russia. This decision positions Tata Steel as the latest multinational corporation to cease operations in the country in response to the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

A spokesperson from Tata Steel Europe stated that the company “does not have any operations or employees in Russia.” They further mentioned that the steel manufacturing units in India, the United Kingdom, and the Netherlands have arranged alternative sources for raw materials, effectively ending reliance on Russian supplies.

With this announcement, Tata Steel joins a small group of Indian companies that have halted their business activities in Russia. Last week, Infosys, India's second-largest information technology firm, declared that it had also suspended its operations in the country.

Meanwhile, the Indian Government has maintained a neutral stance regarding the Russian invasion and has not yet condemned the actions, despite facing pressure from Western nations.

title: China issues preliminary report on China Eastern flight 5735
content:
**Friday, April 22, 2022**

On Wednesday, the Civil Aviation Administration of China (CAAC) released a preliminary report on the crash of China Eastern flight 5735 (MU5735), which resulted in the deaths of 132 passengers and crew members, but did not draw any definitive conclusions regarding the cause of the accident. 

The CAAC report indicated that both recovered flight data recorders were severely damaged and provided no usable information. These recorders have been sent to the National Transportation Safety Board in the United States for further analysis.

MU5735 was traveling from Kunming to Guangzhou on a domestic route when it unexpectedly entered a steep descent and crashed into a mountainside on March 21. The CAAC noted that air traffic controllers had their last communication with the pilots at 2:16 PM local time, while the aircraft was still at a cruising altitude of 29,200 feet (8,900 meters).

title: Indian capital New Delhi reports surge in COVID-19 cases
content:
**Friday, April 22, 2022**

On Wednesday, the Delhi Disaster Management Authority (DDMA) implemented a mask mandate in the National Capital Region as COVID-19 cases surged once again in India’s capital. Authorities announced that violators will face a fine of INR 500 for non-compliance with the mandate. Delhi’s Lieutenant Governor, Anil Baijal, urged residents on Twitter to “ensure strict enforcement of COVID-appropriate behavior.”

On Tuesday, Delhi reported a 26% increase in COVID-19 cases compared to the previous day. Yesterday, India documented 2,067 new COVID-19 cases, with Delhi accounting for 30% of these infections. Additionally, Delhi's positivity rate rose from 4.42% to 5.70%. After experiencing a third wave of the pandemic since January, India’s daily infection numbers had been declining.

Delhi, along with several other states including Kerala, Haryana, Maharashtra, Uttar Pradesh, and Mizoram, has seen a rise in COVID-19 cases over the past few weeks. Rajesh Bhushan, India’s Union Health Secretary, has cautioned states against complacency, emphasizing that it could undermine pandemic management efforts. He also instructed states to closely monitor infection clusters and enhance genome sequencing activities.

title: Flight recorder for fatal China Eastern flight 5735 crash found
content:
Wednesday, March 23, 2022

Aviation officials announced Wednesday that one of the flight data recorders from the crashed China Eastern Airlines flight 5735 has been located. The aircraft, which went down on Monday in Guangxi, China, was carrying 123 passengers and nine crew members.

Mao Yanfeng of the Civil Aviation Authority of China stated that it is not yet clear whether the damaged device is the flight data recorder or the cockpit voice recorder. Authorities are continuing the search for the second recorder, and there is currently no information regarding the integrity of the retrieved data.

The aircraft, a Boeing 737-800, was reported to have a clean maintenance history. Air traffic controllers maintained standard communication with the plane until it suddenly entered a steep dive. As of now, rescue workers have not discovered any survivors from the crash, which occurred in a mountainous area near Wuzhou.

In accordance with standard procedures following accidents involving US-built aircraft, the United States National Transportation Safety Board has appointed a senior investigator to support the Chinese-led investigation. Technical advisors from the US Federal Aviation Administration, as well as representatives from Boeing and CFM International, will also be involved.

title: Former US Secretary of State Albright dies aged 84
content:
**Thursday, March 24, 2022**

Former United States Secretary of State Madeleine Albright has passed away at the age of 84 due to cancer, as announced by her family on Wednesday. 

Albright made history as the first female US Secretary of State, serving from 1997 to 2001 under President Bill Clinton. Prior to that role, she was the US Ambassador to the United Nations from 1993 to 1997.

In honor of her contributions, President Joe Biden has ordered flags at the White House and all federal buildings to be flown at half-mast. He remarked that he "will always remember [Albright's] fervent faith that 'America is the indispensable nation,'" adding, "As the world redefined itself in the wake of the Cold War, we were partners and friends working to welcome newly liberated democracies."

Bill and Hillary Clinton issued a joint statement reflecting on her life: "As a child in war-torn Europe, Madeleine and her family were twice forced to flee their home. When the end of the Cold War ushered in a new era of global interdependence, she became America's voice at the UN, then took the helm at the State Department, where she was a passionate force for freedom, democracy, and human rights."

Former President George W. Bush noted her deep understanding of "the importance of free societies for peace in our world."

Born Marie Jana Korbelová in 1937 in Prague, then part of the First Czechoslovak Republic, Albright’s family fled to exile in 1939 following the Nazi occupation, eventually arriving in the United States in 1948.

title: India grants Novavax Covid-19 vaccine emergency use authorisation for teens
content:
**Thursday, March 24, 2022**

On Tuesday, the Drugs Controller General of India (DCGI) granted emergency use authorization for Novavax's Covid-19 vaccine, Covovax, for teenagers aged 12 to 17. Manufactured by the Serum Institute of India under the brand name Covovax, the vaccine, known as NVX-CoV2373, demonstrated an efficacy rate of 80% in a trial involving 2,247 Indian teenagers in this age group conducted last month.

Additionally, Novavax completed phase three trials in the United States and the United Kingdom for participants aged 18 and older, showing efficacy rates of 90.4% and 89.7%, respectively. Covovax is the first protein-based subunit vaccine to receive authorization in India for this demographic. Last week, India began vaccinating teenagers aged 12 to 14 using Biological E's Corbevax.

Stanley C. Erck, President of Novavax, expressed pride in receiving this approval for adolescents, highlighting the efficacy and safety demonstrated in their data. Adar Poonawalla, CEO of the Serum Institute of India, stated that this decision marks a significant milestone in enhancing the country's immunization efforts.

In December of the previous year, DCGI approved Covovax for emergency use in adults aged 18 and older. The vaccine is also listed for emergency use by the World Health Organization and has been authorized in Indonesia, the Philippines, and Bangladesh.

title: Attack at Texas elementary school kills at least 19, including 18 children
content:
**Wednesday, May 25, 2022**

A tragic shooting at Robb Elementary School in Uvalde, Texas, claimed the lives of at least eighteen young children and a staff member on Tuesday. Reports regarding the number of staff fatalities vary, with estimates ranging from one to three.

The lone suspect in the attack, identified as 18-year-old Salvador Ramos, allegedly shot his grandmother before traveling to the school. Texas Governor Greg Abbott confirmed that Ramos abandoned his vehicle near the school and entered the building armed with a handgun and potentially a rifle. According to WOAI-TV and NPR, Ramos was shot and killed by responding police officers.
